original: Another week just flew by me. I drove by the new house yesterday and the front window was covered in boxes. We may get the keys at closing, i am getting so excited. If all goes well this week, we will be set for closing a week from wednesday. I was up until after 3:00am last night watching movies with bethany. There has been a lot of movie watching going on around here lately. Here's my rundown; last night we watched thirteen, a movie every mother of a teen should see. It was better then i expected. Then we watched gigli, yeah it was just as bad as the media said it was, but we had to see for ourselves.
polished: Another week has flown by. I drove past the new house yesterday and noticed the front window was covered in boxes. We might receive the keys at closing, and I'm getting increasingly excited. If everything goes smoothly this week, we'll be on track for closing a week from Wednesday. I stayed up late last night, watching movies with Bethany until after 3:00am. There's been a movie marathon of sorts going on around here lately. Here's my rundown: last night we watched "Thirteen," a film every mother of a teenager should see. It exceeded my expectations. We also watched "Gigli," which, unfortunately, lived up to its poor reviews, but we had to see it for ourselves.

original: Summer tv tv in the summer used to be a dead zone full of repeats or something. But now there are two great new shows on tv and i have been watching both religiously for the last week. Blow out the gayest concept ever that seemingly has zero gay people in sight. Hairstylist jonothan antin wants build a second location to his incredibly popular west hollywood salon but this time in beverly hills. Normally no one would care, certainly not i, but as i was flipping thru the channels i caught a glipse of jonothan, equally narcissistic and dull looking at a empty space on rodeo dr speak (in a public voice) 'i am going to build here the greatest salon in the history of the world ever!' and i was hooked. Not since rocco have i found such a moron compelling tv watching.
polished: Summer TV used to be a dead zone filled with repeats, but now there are two great new shows that have caught my attention. I've been watching them religiously for the past week. One of them, "Blow Out," has a concept that's almost laughably over-the-top, yet somehow lacks any visible gay presence. The show revolves around hairstylist Jonathan Antin, who wants to expand his incredibly popular West Hollywood salon to a second location in Beverly Hills. Normally, this wouldn't be of interest to me, but while flipping through channels, I caught a glimpse of Jonathan, who exudes equal parts narcissism and dullness, standing in an empty space on Rodeo Drive and proclaiming, "I'm going to build the greatest salon in the history of the world!" I was hooked. It's been a while since I've found someone as moronically compelling as Rocco, making for some entertaining TV.

original: What a week ... My right shoulder has tendonitus. It's right under my shoulder blade. So, when i move my arm too much, mainly with a mouse on a computer .... It kills me. I can't move it much now because i was on a spree updating my website and working on other online things. I can barely get up strength to draw anything. Lack of sleep adds to my pain. I'm not too happy right now, but i'll get better. My mom's surgery went ok. Her eyesight has come back some. She can see fuzzy shapes and make out colors. Other than that she's still blind as all sin. Hopefully she'll fully regain her vision soon.
polished: What a week... I've developed tendonitis in my right shoulder, just under my shoulder blade. Whenever I move my arm excessively, particularly when using a computer mouse, it's excruciating. Unfortunately, I've been on a marathon updating my website and working on other online projects, which has left me with limited mobility. I'm struggling to muster the strength to draw anything. The lack of sleep isn't helping, either. I'm not in the best of spirits right now, but I'm optimistic about a full recovery. On a more positive note, my mom's surgery was successful, and her eyesight has started to return. She can now see blurry shapes and distinguish colors, although her vision is still severely impaired. Hopefully, she'll regain her full vision soon.

original: Kindness of strangers... Attempted laundry today with the kids in tow and realized how very quickly the simplest things can become a freaking ordeal. I also learned how remarkably sweet total strangers can be for no reason other than because they feel like being sweet. Trust me. It wasn't like they were trying to get into my pants or anything. I had kid drool all over me and was wearing my 'wash-day' outfit... Also, i'm not surper sure i'll ever be bathing again so it's not like there was even an olefactory incentive there! i am doing two things right now. I am composing an post and i am also watching the collected no doubt videos. I am doing both of these things sitting at my desk in my room.
polished: The kindness of strangers... I attempted to do laundry today with the kids in tow and quickly realized how the simplest tasks can escalate into a chaotic ordeal. However, I also discovered the remarkable kindness of total strangers, who showed compassion for no reason other than the fact that they felt like being kind. Rest assured, it wasn't about ulterior motives - I was covered in kid drool and wearing my casual 'wash-day' outfit, hardly a sight to behold. To be honest, I'm not sure when I'll be bathing again, so there wasn't even an olfactory incentive. Currently, I'm multitasking - composing this post while watching a collection of No Doubt music videos, all from the comfort of my desk in my room.

original: So it is 11:14pm mst, and here i sit in my bedroom fixing the personal computer of the personnel director from my job. Not that i mind doing it, but i wonder sometimes at how often i find myself fixing someone else's computer as a favour. I'm glad to be able to love and minister to people this way, but where is the line drawn where it comes to the point that you are being taken advantage of? the last couple of weeks, i've been staying up late reading and such, so i was looking forward to hitting the sack early, until i realized it would be more prudent to get this computer out of my bedroom and back into its owner's hands. *laugh* no rest for the weary, right? so i found myself watching joe schmo 2 again tonight.
polished: It's 11:14pm MST, and I'm sitting in my bedroom, fixing the personal computer of our personnel director from work. I don't mind doing favors, but I often wonder how frequently I end up fixing someone else's computer. I'm glad I can show love and care for people in this way, but I do question where the line is drawn before I'm taken advantage of. The past couple of weeks have been late nights spent reading, so I was looking forward to an early night's sleep, until I realized it would be more practical to return this computer to its owner as soon as possible. No rest for the weary, indeed. Instead, I found myself watching Joe Schmo 2 again tonight.

original: Remind me, what did i write about before this? or, a continuation in the 'is this a date?' saga so, after the weird lunch, my confidence shook, i forgot to tell you guys an important piece of the story. Before pat shows up to lunch, dustin starts talking about what a nice guy pat is and how he's trying to find a girlfriend for him. I'm listening and nodding and realizing that we're talking more about finding dustin's best friend a girl, than discussing whatever it is you discuss with a stranger over pink lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, looked in the mirror and then silently asked myself: am i being pawned off to the other guy? is this what happens now?
polished: Remind me, what was I discussing before this, or is this a continuation of the 'is this a date?' saga? Following the awkward lunch, my confidence took a hit. I forgot to share a crucial part of the story with you all. Before Pat arrived for lunch, Dustin started talking about what a great guy Pat is and how he's trying to find him a girlfriend. As I listened and nodded, I realized we were spending more time discussing finding a girl for Dustin's best friend than engaging in typical conversation with a stranger over pink lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, caught a glimpse of myself in the mirror, and silently wondered: am I being set up with the other guy? Is this how things are supposed to go now?

original: I would like everyone to think before they act. Actually.. I'd like each and every single person in the world to think before they get out of bed in the morning, and make a commitment to keep thinking all day, and if they're not prepared to, i'd like very much that they'd hop the fuck back in bed, and drift off to an eternal slumber. I'm sick to death of stupid people. No i'm not the smartest motherfucker in the world... But i'm not talking about things that take a lot of brain power, so i think its fair to persecute the inanely stupid. Lets see if i can keep this particular rant to a few particular types, and we'll save some for another day, sound good? great.
polished: I wish everyone would think before acting. Ideally, I'd like every person in the world to start their day with a commitment to think critically, and maintain that mindset throughout. If they're not willing to do so, I'd rather they stayed in bed and avoided causing harm. I'm exhausted by the prevalence of thoughtless behavior. I'm not claiming to be the most intelligent person, but I'm not advocating for complex thinking either. I believe it's reasonable to hold people accountable for their inexcusable lack of common sense. Let's focus on a few specific examples for now and save the rest for another time, if that sounds agreeable.

original: Two problems with the scenario outlined in my previous post: 1. True, bush is stimulating the economy, but in the wrong way. Urllink robert rubin told npr's marketplace today that bush could have achieved the same stimulus effect without the long term debt hangover by enacting different tax cuts, temporary tax cuts that would benefit low and middle income persons. Ah, robert rubin. The sound of his name is music to our ears. Quick: name one bush administration cabinet official on the domestic side with rubin's gravitas. Still thinking? it'll come to you... 2. We can't give the republicans control only in wartime because they've ingeniously concocted an endless, global 'war on terrorism.'
polished: Two issues with the scenario outlined in my previous post: 1. While it's true that Bush is stimulating the economy, he's doing so in an unideal manner. Robert Rubin, in an interview with NPR's Marketplace, pointed out that the same stimulus effect could have been achieved without incurring long-term debt by implementing temporary tax cuts that would benefit low- and middle-income individuals. The mention of Robert Rubin's name is indeed a welcome sound. It's worth noting that among Bush administration cabinet officials on the domestic side, few possess the same level of gravitas as Rubin. 2. We cannot afford to give Republicans control solely during wartime, as they have effectively created a perpetual, global 'war on terrorism' that shows no signs of abating.

original: 'she's saying i'm on the run, i'm chasing guys for fun' ~the offspring umm haven't updated in awhile but not much to say.. Went to the cove to see supernothing, they were good as usual, got to chill with tiago :-).. Sat. Went to work and then out w/ joe and rach, met up with steve, tiago and tom.. Came home at like quarter to 12 and woke up the next morning at quarter to 7 for a meet.. Got there a little late but it's all good, i did my full on floor and didn't fall, second on floor and vault and third on beam, 29.45 all around which isn't bad bc my meets get better as the season goes on..
polished: 'She's saying I'm on the run, I'm chasing guys for fun' ~The Offspring. It's been a while since my last update, but not much has changed. I recently visited The Cove to watch Supernothin', and they were as great as ever. I also got to hang out with Tiago, which was nice. On Saturday, I went to work and then met up with Joe and Rach. We later joined Steve, Tiago, and Tom. I got home around 11:45 PM and woke up the next morning at 6:45 AM for a meet. Although I arrived a bit late, everything turned out fine. I completed my full routine on the floor without falling, placing second on floor and vault, and third on beam. My all-around score was 29.45, which isn't bad considering my meets tend to improve as the season progresses.

original: Do you ever have one of those moments when you begin to reflect on life? like you're sitting in math class bored out of your skull, and you wonder what exactly goes on in your brain that makes you understand math? and you realize that you exist and you are in math class and you wonder why. Then you realize how amazing existing is. And suddenly it hits you-the fact that you are going off on this random train of thought is incredibly pathetic. Ever had that happen? i hate that. You know what else i hate? block schedules. Who would ever come up with that idea? anyone can see that sitting through a two and a half hour class in any subject is cruel and unusual punishment.
polished: Have you ever experienced one of those moments where you pause to reflect on life? Perhaps you're sitting in a math class, feeling utterly bored, and you start to wonder what processes in your brain enable you to comprehend math. You then realize your existence and the fact that you're in math class, prompting you to question the purpose of it all. This realization can be quite profound, as you begin to appreciate the beauty of simply existing. However, this train of thought is often short-lived, as you suddenly feel a pang of embarrassment at the randomness of your musings. It's a feeling that can be quite frustrating. On a related note, I have a strong dislike for block schedules. Who would conceive of such an idea? It's clear that sitting through a two-and-a-half-hour class in any subject is a form of cruel and unusual punishment.

original: I think that monpoly has run it's course in my life and i vow to never lay my hands on that damn iron (not a hot one but the piece in the game) again. Tonight andy beat me by a few small dollars and won the farquin game, or maybe i let him win on account of him leaving in a few short hours and me wanting him to feel good on his last night here. Well how ever the story goes it can't compare to this texas sized headache i have at the moment, i've taken some aleve and i must say that they are doing the trick, all i need now is some well deserved r&r your telephone's the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck... At the drive in
polished: I believe that Monopoly has run its course in my life, and I vow to never lay my hands on that iron game piece again. Tonight, Andy beat me by a few small dollars and won the game, or perhaps I let him win, considering he's leaving in a few short hours and I wanted him to feel good on his last night here. Whatever the story may be, it can't compare to this Texas-sized headache I have at the moment. I've taken some Aleve, and I must say they're doing the trick; all I need now is some well-deserved rest and relaxation. Your telephone's the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck... At the drive-in.

original: Well... Today's been a long day. We had to drive home from indiana. I guess i'm gonna sort of have to be choosy what i write about because i could really take up a lot of time and space and i just don't have enough energy. First off i have to say that camp was awesome and even better than i could have expected. God's been doing so much stuff in my life lately and it's just awesome. I've sort of turned over a new leaf i guess, but anyway's back to the beginning. We arrived at the twiggs' house on friday evening and we stayed until we left for camp on monday. Most of what we did was go to the fair, church, a parade, walmart and watched movies.
polished: Today's been a long day, having driven home from Indiana. I'll have to be selective about what I write, as I could easily fill a lot of space and time, but I'm running low on energy. To start, I have to say that camp was incredible, exceeding my expectations in every way. Lately, God has been doing some amazing things in my life, and it's truly awesome. I feel like I've turned a new leaf, but I'll get back to the beginning. We arrived at the Twiggs' house on Friday evening and stayed until we left for camp on Monday. During our visit, we attended the fair, church, a parade, went to Walmart, and watched movies.

original: Today is my last day of summer vacation! waaaaaa! and i have a dentist appointment at 9. I hate that, but i'd rather get it over with than try to schedule it during the first month of my surgery rotation. I'm definitely nervous, scared, jittery, and any other words you can think up for 'hell's no, me's don wanna go' to school. This is going to be a whole new ball game for me. As a perfectionist, i love excelling at everything i do. But starting new things is a bitch. I hate being a pawn (like i told cassie: 'i'm going to be the only pawn on the chessboard who insists on moving like a knight'), and i hate not knowing what's going on.
polished: Today marks the end of my summer vacation, and I'm not exactly thrilled about it. To make matters worse, I have a dentist appointment at 9. While I'm not looking forward to it, I'd rather get it over with now than try to squeeze it in during the first month of my surgery rotation. I'm feeling anxious, apprehensive, and more than a little resistant to the idea of going back to school. This is going to be a whole new challenge for me. As a perfectionist, I thrive on excelling in everything I do, but starting anew is daunting. I dislike being uncertain and out of control, like a pawn on a chessboard, and I especially hate not knowing what to expect.

original: Arun shourie talks about how, the present governor of uttar pradesh had warned, as far back as 1996, about the impending threat of the rise of a urllink ' third islamic state ' in the subcontinent . T v rajeswar, the former head of the intelligence bureau and the present governor of uttar pradesh had predicted this dire threat in a series of articles published in the hindustan times, way back in 1996. Shourie raises a valid point when he says, does the fact that you now know that he, and not i, to say nothing of mr advani, wrote all that make the warnings ring true? or do you conclude that because he wrote in this refrain, t v rajeswar is a closet communalist and should not be allowed to continue as governor of uttar pradesh?
polished: Arun Shourie discusses how the current Governor of Uttar Pradesh had warned as far back as 1996 about the impending threat of the rise of a 'third Islamic state' in the subcontinent. T V Rajeswar, the former head of the Intelligence Bureau and the present Governor of Uttar Pradesh, had predicted this dire threat in a series of articles published in the Hindustan Times in 1996. Shourie raises a valid point when he asks, does the fact that it is now known that Rajeswar, rather than himself or Mr. Advani, wrote these warnings make them ring true? Or do we conclude that because Rajeswar expressed these concerns, he is a closet communalist and should not be allowed to continue as Governor of Uttar Pradesh?

original: Attitude: bored mood: indifferent, looking forward to tonight been a long hard day in the trenches here today folks, almost no time to write anything for you readers. However it's good to see tigger(now akcron) taking up the reigns herself and making an appearance and talking about things :) not much to say about things, yesterday was shakespeare on the green, was a lovely play, but i had to leave before closing curtain, which kinda sucked, hopefully someday i'll see the entirety of a shakespeare play. But i digress. Akcron is right about the problems with the shower, it sucks, in terms of laughing at her in the shower, you have to admit, the look people get when committing self torture can be pretty entertaining.
polished: Attitude: bored, mood: indifferent, but looking forward to tonight. It's been a long, arduous day in the trenches, leaving little time to write for my readers. On a brighter note, it's great to see Tigger (now Akcron) taking the reins and making an appearance, sharing her thoughts. Unfortunately, I don't have much to share today. Yesterday's Shakespeare on the Green was a lovely play, although I had to leave before the final curtain, which was disappointing. Hopefully, I'll get to see a complete Shakespeare play someday. As an aside, Akcron is spot on about the issues with the shower - it's subpar. However, I must admit that witnessing someone's reaction to self-inflicted discomfort can be quite amusing, especially in the shower.

original: All of a sudden, for the past two days, i have been overcome with terrible bouts of exhaustion. Bone dead exhaustion. Last evening, i went home, and just slept off, and only got up when my mother called me around eight thirty. And when i woke up, it was all dark, and i hadn't switched the lights on, so i could not figure out what time or date it was, for a few seconds, it was just my mother's voice in the darkness and me grappling with reality. Wonder why i'm feeling so drained... Nice weather this morning. It was drizzling when i came. Although in calcutta i hear it's been raining for the past three days.
polished: Over the past two days, I've been unexpectedly overcome with severe bouts of exhaustion - a bone-dead fatigue. Last evening, I went home and slept off, only waking up when my mother called me around 8:30. When I woke up, it was dark, and I hadn't switched on the lights, so for a few seconds, I was disoriented, with only my mother's voice in the darkness as I struggled to grasp reality. I'm still wondering why I'm feeling so drained. This morning, however, the weather was pleasant, with a gentle drizzle when I arrived. In contrast, I've heard that it's been raining in Calcutta for the past three days.

original: Last night was the worst. I threw away the sweater i was knitting. I only had about 14 inches. I lost probably $10 worth of yarn (it's $8 a skein). But it had too many stitches by the time i got to the arm holes and the mohair was knotting itself together as i knitted, so frogging (ripping out rows) didn't work well. The yarn broke a lot. I didn't even swear, which is unusual for me. I just morosely ripped and listened to season two of sex and the city (way to go, library!). And then i got sick of it and threw it away. I suppose i could say i learned a lot while trying to do this sweater.
polished: Last night was a disaster. I ended up discarding the sweater I was knitting, which was about 14 inches long. I likely lost around $10 worth of yarn, considering it costs $8 per skein. Unfortunately, the project had become unmanageable by the time I reached the armholes, with too many stitches and the mohair constantly knotting itself together as I knitted. As a result, frogging didn't work well, and the yarn kept breaking. Surprisingly, I didn't even swear, which is out of character for me. Instead, I morosely ripped out the rows while listening to season two of Sex and the City, courtesy of the library. Eventually, I grew tired of it and threw the sweater away. I suppose I can say that I gained valuable experience from attempting to make this sweater.

original: Last night in class, we were discussing that week’s assigned reading, urllink getting back into place: toward a renewed study of the place-world, by edward s. Casey . The first chapter deals with “implacement” and the second, “displacement.” in the first chapter, casey makes the distinction that our contemporary world and culture revolves around time as the situating force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. He is trying to make the case that using place as the center of culture gives a more grounded community. (that is a very rough summation, a disclaimer just in case my professor or any other classmate happens to read this post.) so far, this book is the first reading that has grabbed me by the proverbial shoulders.
polished: Last night in class, we delved into that week's assigned reading, "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World" by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter explores "implacement" and the second, "displacement." In the first chapter, Casey distinguishes that our contemporary world and culture are centered around time as the primary situating force, where phrases like "running out of time," "saving time," and "just in time" dominate our discourse. He argues that by placing place at the heart of culture, we can foster a more grounded community. (Please note that this is a rough summary, and I offer this disclaimer in case my professor or classmates happen to read this post.) So far, this book is the first reading that has truly resonated with me.

original: Whatever it is they put into freeze pops to make them those colours, there should be some sort of warning: may make your life a bit bizarre. And whilst giggling is good, one wonders if we would have found ourselves up that fire escape drinking beer in the fierce wind had we not been eating them earlier. Finding ourselves in a doorway to a bar sadly closed for business, we stopped to examine an office-supplies catalogue that had arrived in the post. Lucky we did. Who could possibly have guessed that within these pages were the special offers of a lifetime? not i, for certain. I list but a few: buy 36 permanent marker pens, get a stunt kite. Buy 30 lever arch files, get a barbecue.
polished: Whatever it is they put into freeze pops to make them those vibrant colours, there should be some sort of warning label: may make your life a bit more bizarre. And while giggling is good for you, one can't help but wonder if we would have found ourselves climbing up that fire escape, drinking beer in the fierce wind, had we not been consuming them earlier. Finding ourselves in front of a doorway to a bar that was sadly closed for business, we stopped to browse through an office-supplies catalogue that had arrived in the mail. Fortunately, we did. Who could have possibly guessed that within these pages lay the special offers of a lifetime? Certainly not I. To name a few: purchase 36 permanent marker pens, receive a stunt kite free. Buy 30 lever arch files, get a complimentary barbecue.

original: Currently listening to: the little drummer boy by stevan pasero ...and now my post... Senate republicans okay, hands up - who watched the 39-hour judicial nominations wankathon last week? i know i didn't. Well, okay - i did tune in once or twice. The entire colossal waste of time was perpetrated by republicans who, pissed off that democrats wouldn't roll over and nominate four of bush's nutjob justices, were trying to score political points by holding a multi-day cry-fest. Never mind the fact that the democrats have already approved 168 of bush's judicial nominees - nooo, that's not good enough for the power-mad republicans who are for some reason laboring under the misapprehension they have a huge mandate for this kind of nonsense.
polished: Currently listening to: The Little Drummer Boy by Stevan Pasero. Now, onto my post. Senate Republicans, hands up – who watched the 39-hour judicial nominations marathon last week? I know I didn't, although I did tune in briefly a couple of times. The entire colossal waste of time was orchestrated by Republicans, who were furious that Democrats wouldn't rubber-stamp four of Bush's contentious judicial nominees. They attempted to score political points by staging a multi-day protest. It's worth noting that Democrats have already approved 168 of Bush's judicial nominees – apparently, that's not enough for the power-hungry Republicans, who seem to be operating under the misconception that they have a massive mandate for this kind of behavior.

original: This was a good weekend. I did a lot of god's green leaf, after a long time, i listened to a lot of nevermore (something i should have started doing much earlier) and read a lot. I finished three books over the weekend - bruce sterling's heavy weather, larry niven's world of ptavvs and octavia butler's parable of the sower. Heavy weather was a good cyberpunk romp through a near-future usa, devastated by global warming and general anarchy. While it was clever, well-paced and altogether very convincing, i must confess that i failed to come away with any really significant sensations about the story or the characters. Not that both aren't well constructed and vividly etched - it's a good book, but not a great one, i guess.
polished: This was a great weekend. I spent a lot of time outdoors, reconnecting with nature after a long hiatus, and rediscovered my love for Nevermore's music, something I should have done much sooner. I also managed to get a lot of reading done, finishing three books - Bruce Sterling's Heavy Weather, Larry Niven's World of Ptavvs, and Octavia Butler's Parable of the Sower. Heavy Weather was an engaging cyberpunk adventure set in a near-future USA ravaged by global warming and chaos. Although it was clever, well-paced, and convincingly portrayed, I have to admit that it didn't leave a lasting impression on me. The story and characters were well-crafted and vivid, but overall, it was a good book, rather than a great one.

original: Coz' this is the aftermath the first week back from practicum was a struggle but it is only in the second week that the smoke has really started to clear. Post-practicum trauma was a hidden epidemic that is only now coming to light. I was stricken but with the eventual meeting with the course co-ordinator allowed me to release my burden and by doing so i have prevented another person being stuck with such a pedagogically deficit practicum school. Yesterday (monday) i bumped into another agrieved classmate who was quite determined to go to the student who was due to go to her school in the next practicum and tell him how terrible it will be. I calmed her down and said that we should go to the administrator first.
polished: Because this is the aftermath, the first week back from practicum was a struggle, but it's only in the second week that the smoke has really started to clear. Post-practicum trauma is a hidden epidemic that is only now coming to light. I was stricken, but an eventual meeting with the course coordinator allowed me to release my burden, and by doing so, I have prevented another person from being stuck with such a pedagogically deficient practicum school. Yesterday, Monday, I bumped into another aggrieved classmate who was quite determined to warn the student due to go to her school in the next practicum about how terrible it would be. I calmed her down and suggested that we should approach the administrator first.

original: Well, things are incredibly busy here at times...but there's always time for supposed stress relieving activities. I've found that i really suck at 8-ball and ping pong! rick(the canuck) beats my ass on a regular basis - we have a ping pong table in the front lobby of our building, always time for a 'quick round'. Last night i participated in an 8-ball tournament over at the hot spot (our recreation tent - complete with popcorn machine, numerous tv's, jukebox, dvd rental, pool table, dart board, and ever present ping pong table). Anyway, i was doing pretty well throughout my one entire game - until i scratched on the eight ball ;( i still had a fairly good time - the most fun was the two dutch soldiers that joined in the tournament.
polished: Things are incredibly busy here at times, but there's always time for supposed stress-relieving activities. I've discovered that I'm not very skilled at 8-ball and ping pong. Rick, the Canuck, consistently beats me, and we often squeeze in a quick round on the ping pong table in our building's front lobby. Last night, I participated in an 8-ball tournament at the Hot Spot, our recreation tent equipped with a popcorn machine, multiple TVs, a jukebox, DVD rentals, a pool table, a dartboard, and a ping pong table. Although I was doing fairly well throughout my one game, I ultimately scratched on the eight ball. Despite the loss, I still had a good time, particularly with the two Dutch soldiers who joined the tournament.

original: Fall 1974: i was attempting for what felt like the 13th time to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then nor am i now a math person. I hate math. I am math phobic. You get the picture. So as i struggled to make sense out of algebra the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to open the door. No one was there. Great. I returned to my studies and just as i was finding a little glimmer of understanding buried in my sub conscious the doorbell rang again. Bam, just like that my breakthrough disappeared. I went to the door and once again no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs, an uninvited practical joker.
polished: Fall 1974: I was attempting, for what felt like the thirteenth time, to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then, nor am I now, a math person - I hate math and have a deep-seated phobia of it. You get the picture. As I struggled to make sense of algebra, the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to open the door, only to find no one there. Great, just what I needed. I returned to my studies and just as I was finding a glimmer of understanding buried in my subconscious, the doorbell rang again. My breakthrough vanished instantly. I went to the door, and once again, no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs - an uninvited practical joker.

original: This past week has been nothing short of exhausting. I spent tuesday-thursday finishing the move to my new classroom. The new room is bigger and closer to my grade level team, these are the things i need to consider as i spend hours upon hours preparing my room for this year. Had i known i was going to move prior to the end of my school year, i would have discarded much of the books and supplies i no longer use. Unfortunately, it all came with me. So this week was spent moving, unpacking, and purging profusely. I have to thank my teammate jill for helping with all of this. You see, she was still teaching this month, in my old room. So she and her lovely students moved almost my entire room for me!
polished: This past week has been nothing short of exhausting. I spent Tuesday through Thursday completing the move to my new classroom. The new room is bigger and closer to my grade level team, factors I must consider as I spend hours preparing it for the year. Had I known about the move prior to the end of the school year, I would have discarded many of the books and supplies I no longer use. Unfortunately, everything came with me. As a result, this week was spent moving, unpacking, and purging extensively. I must thank my teammate Jill for her assistance with all of this. Since she was still teaching in my old room this month, she and her students kindly moved almost my entire room for me.

original: You can't help it, you can't evade it: a piece of you will always live in me. Even if i never carried you child, even if i was never married to you, even if i was never an official pair to you ... I loved you immensely, and to this day the feeling carries an echo through my heart. Forever will i always be reminded of the very few nights we spent together, hearts and limbs entwined in a soul-embrace, drenched in the salty darkness of an evening by the beach ... Or a kiss under the rain. Whenever i get the feeling of a dark glass puncturing my heart, you will be there. That piece of you... Bleeding the eternal love that once lived in me ... And still remains. .. For heri
polished: You can't escape it, a part of you will forever be a part of me. Even if I never carried your child, even if we were never married, even if we were never officially a couple... I loved you deeply, and to this day, that feeling still resonates within my heart. I will always be reminded of the few nights we shared, our hearts and bodies entwined in a soulful embrace, bathed in the salty darkness of a beachside evening... or a kiss under the rain. Whenever a pang of sorrow pierces my heart, you will be there, that piece of you... bleeding the eternal love that once burned within me... and still remains. For heri.

original: I'm uncomfortable. Investigative reporting seems very wrong to me. Or let me rephrase that, the article i'm doing and it's consequences is not exactly something i'm comfortable with. Perhaps it is because i don't believe in it enough, that i cannot really get the complete feel for it. The angst behind it. The full-out passion towards it to question. I've grown up in a country where you don't ask questions. Really, you just don't. They shoot you for that shit. They put you in jail with all these internal security acts. I am not used to this freedom of speech...not used to questioning out loud. Sure, i am not the easiest person to get along with.
polished: I'm uneasy about this. Investigative reporting doesn't sit well with me, or rather, the article I'm working on and its implications make me uncomfortable. Maybe it's because I don't fully believe in it, which makes it hard for me to grasp the underlying emotions and passion that drive it. The fervor to question and challenge is something I'm not accustomed to. Growing up in a country where questioning authority was discouraged, and often met with severe consequences, including imprisonment and worse, has made me wary of exercising my freedom of speech. I'm not used to voicing my doubts openly, and I'm aware that I can be difficult to get along with.

original: We had an outing yesterday with my co-employees at the bank. We went to guintubdan, la carolota. It was the first time for most of us. We trekked for the falls. It was a 30 minute or so walk. We were all catching our breaths. Whew! but we made it. The water was chilly ice. You can feel your body getting numb because of the coldness. We only stayed less than an hour because we headed for the nearby waterfalls. Another 30 minutes of trekking. But the trip was worth it because the falls looked calming and the whole scene is indeed breathtaking. Its like you can hear yourself being one with nature. Soaking myself in the cold water was like communing with mother earth. The cold air and water were enough to make you be lulled to sleep.
polished: We had an outing with my bank colleagues yesterday at Guintubdan, La Carolota. For most of us, it was our first time visiting the area. We embarked on a trek to the falls, which took around 30 minutes and left us all catching our breath. However, the effort was worthwhile as we finally reached our destination. The icy cold water was invigorating, and its chilliness was palpable, making our bodies feel numb. We only stayed for less than an hour before heading to the nearby waterfalls, which required another 30-minute trek. The trip was well worth it, though, as the falls exuded a calming ambiance, and the scenery was truly breathtaking. Being surrounded by nature was almost meditative, and I felt at one with the environment. Soaking in the cold water was like communing with Mother Earth, and the combination of the chilly air and water was so soothing that it could have lulled me to sleep.

original: Well i am sure my sisters are drunk off their butts. Today was pride in san diego. I know my sisters and when it is drinking time, it is drinking time. It is the one thing i didn't get from the buenviajes, the want to drink. There are few times i don't mind drinking but let's just say they are very rare times. So we have a month left before ed leaves. I think it is starting to sink in with ed and with all of us. I think it sunk in with me a long time ago. I just hope that ed will be here for bailey's surgery. We have been keeping an eye on his swelling and there definitely is quite a bit of swelling.
polished: I'm fairly certain my sisters are intoxicated. Today was Pride in San Diego, and I know my sisters - when it's time to drink, they don't hold back. It's one trait I didn't inherit from the Buenviajes, the desire to drink. While I do enjoy drinking on rare occasions, those instances are few and far between. With only a month left before Ed leaves, I think the reality of the situation is starting to sink in for Ed and the rest of us. For me, it's been a long time coming. I just hope Ed will be here for Bailey's surgery. We've been monitoring his swelling, and unfortunately, there's noticeable swelling.

original: Saturday we took connor to firemans park, thinking that the fireman's easter egg hunt was to start at 11am. It turned out it was on the friday. Thank goodness i brought a bag of eggs with me just incase. So connor had a great time finding eggs out in the park. Sunday morning when he woke up he was so excited that the easter bunny had come. There is nothing better then to see the excitement on your childs face. After egg hunting, we all went to church. Even though the 'easter bunny' is fun and all. We do make sure our kids know the true meaning of the holidays. This was megan's first easter, she looked so cute dressed in her jean dress and stockings :)
polished: On Saturday, we took Connor to Fireman's Park, assuming the Easter egg hunt was scheduled for 11am. However, it turned out to be on Friday. Fortunately, I had brought a bag of eggs as a precaution, so Connor still had a great time searching for them in the park. On Sunday morning, he woke up thrilled to discover that the Easter bunny had visited. There's nothing quite like seeing the excitement on your child's face. Following the egg hunt, we attended church as a family. While the Easter bunny is a fun tradition, we make sure our kids understand the true meaning behind the holiday. This was Megan's first Easter, and she looked adorable in her jean dress and stockings.

original: I know in a previous post i protected parents, almost even taking their side, well here's my little change of mind. Parents don't know anything. They think they know you soooo well, maybe even to the point where they can read emotions off your face. They can't. Parents know nothing about us. And when i go upstairs after arguing with nicole about kelli, like i just did a few minutes ago, and they want me to tell them what's wrong. Yeah, how about you shut the fuck up!? i don't have to tell you what's wrong all the time. Here's the situation with nicole and kelli. Kelli and nicole don't like each other. At all.
polished: I've had a change of heart since my previous post, where I defended parents and almost took their side. Now, I'm not so sure. The truth is, parents don't know as much as they think they do. They believe they can read us like a book, deciphering our emotions just by looking at our faces. But the reality is, they have no idea. When I stormed upstairs after a heated argument with Nicole about Kelli, my parents wanted to know what was wrong. My response? They don't need to know everything. The situation with Nicole and Kelli is simple: they just don't get along.

original: Urllink some people are jumping to connect urllink this dot : the urllink organization for security and cooperation in europe was invited to monitor the election by the state department. The observers will come from the osce's office for democratic institutions and human rights. It will be the first time such a team has been present for a u.s. Presidential election. With urllink this dot : a baker's dozen of congressional democrats, among them four new yorkers, has petitioned u.n. Secretary- general kofi annan to dispatch international observers to florida to oversee this year's presidential balloting there. I humbly disagree. Based on the info available, the osce seems to be coming here to learn from the u.s. Election process, not to oversee it, which was the original partisan and childish call for u.n.
polished: Some people are jumping to connect the dots: the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe was invited by the State Department to monitor the election. The observers will come from the OSCE's Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights. This will mark the first time such a team has been present for a U.S. presidential election. Meanwhile, a baker's dozen of congressional Democrats, including four New Yorkers, has petitioned U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan to dispatch international observers to Florida to oversee this year's presidential balloting there. I humbly disagree. Based on the available information, the OSCE appears to be coming to learn from the U.S. election process, rather than to oversee it, which was the original partisan and childish call for U.N. intervention.

polished: My heinous mood has lifted. The combination of an impending period and forgetting to take Prozac until late in the day had left me feeling extremely sad and tearful. However, a surprise visit from my boyfriend, an ice cream sundae, and the comfort of holding his hand after a terrifying dream in which people started firing machine guns at the news bureau greatly improved my mood. I'm also relieved to have the morning off, but I do need to make a call to a man at KMIZ to obtain his rate card. Tonight, I'm looking forward to spending time with two of my closest friends, Amy and Kate, and hopefully squeezing in some study time. Tomorrow, I might also get to see someone I haven't seen in a while for our WW date.

polished: A lot has been happening lately... Debbie and I got into a dispute over the type of china I was allowed to use. I mean, seriously, do you really need to bring out the expensive china to feed an entire church choir? Anyway, she had an impressive array of dishes - saucers, teapots, coffee cups, wine goblets, water glasses, seven different types of forks and spoons, dinner plates, salad plates, dessert plates, soup bowls, and side bowls. I was taken aback. Then, she scolded me for eating appetizers while the turkey was cooking. I stood my ground, insisting I would eat what I wanted. After that, we had to rush to the hospital with my father.

original: Gop gets scolded on recruitment naturalization ceremonies in jacksonville are to be relocated after complaints that gop activists registered new citizens as republicans. By gary fineout and alfonso chardy the citizenship ceremony in jacksonville seemed to go off as usual, with a crowd of nearly 200 people going home as new americans. Just before the new citizens left the june 29 event, an immigration official directing the swearing-in urged them to stop by a voter registration table -- a not uncommon sight at naturalization ceremonies. But this table was unusual: those handing out forms were republican volunteers -- and the party affiliation box had been checked off ahead of time to make all of the new voters members of the gop. All of it was suspicious to linda cross, who was there to watch her husband, dario cruz, take his citizenship oath.
polished: A GOP-backed voter registration effort at a naturalization ceremony in Jacksonville has sparked controversy, prompting relocation of future events. By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy, the June 29 citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville appeared to proceed as usual, with nearly 200 people departing as new US citizens. Just before the new citizens left, an immigration official overseeing the swearing-in ceremony encouraged them to visit a nearby voter registration table, a common sight at naturalization events. However, this particular table was unusual, as it was staffed by Republican volunteers, and the party affiliation box on the registration forms had been pre-checked to automatically register new voters as Republicans. This raised suspicions among attendees, including Linda Cross, who was present to witness her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath.

original: I have always prided myself in making anyone that frequents casa pescatore as comforable as possible. I want them to make sure they feel at home as they will feel in their prospective residence. Yesterday- i hope i succeeded. The masses all congregated on perry ave with what many consider ' extreme prejudice'. 4:30pm was the time my best friend eric and his son nunu came over with a huge pan of baked ziti. The tables were set and i had all the food that i cooked and the bells were ringing crazy. Before i could blink - my best friend from florida walked through the door and that made me smile. I missed that motherfucker so much. The bonus was him bringing his wife along. She is expecting and this is the closest i could get to being an uncle. I spoiled that girl with tray after tray of food and tiramisu.
polished: I've always taken pride in making every guest at Casa Pescatore feel as comfortable as possible, just as they would in their own home. Yesterday, I hoped to have succeeded in doing so. The gathering on Perry Avenue was a lively one, with many in attendance. At 4:30 pm, my best friend Eric and his son Nunu arrived with a large pan of baked ziti. The tables were set, and the food I had prepared was ready. The doorbell rang nonstop, and before I knew it, my dear friend from Florida walked in, bringing a huge smile to my face. I had missed him dearly. The added surprise was that he brought his wife along, who is expecting - a thrilling experience for me, as I'll get to be an uncle of sorts. I spoiled her with an abundance of food and tiramisu, tray after tray.

original: I liked the idea of that as an offence - maybe that could've been a way out of being burned as a witch. As a non-american blogger i've been a little reluctant to get involved in some of these discussions, particularly the bits about flags, but since i started it (the subject, not the flag-burning) i suppose i'd better say something. Firstly, i think that the idea of having a law against flag-burning is completely nuts. The moment you start according a symbol - any symbol - that kind of automatic reverence and protection, you've taken a small but important step towards totalitarianism. Symbols are kind of fickle - they don't a priori represent anything in themselves; it's what they are perceived as meaning or made to represent that's important.
polished: I found the idea of that as an offense intriguing - it could have been a viable alternative to being persecuted as a witch. As a non-American blogger, I've been somewhat hesitant to engage in certain discussions, particularly those surrounding flags, but since I initiated the topic, I suppose I should offer my thoughts. Firstly, I believe that enacting a law against flag-burning is utterly absurd. The moment you grant a symbol - any symbol - such automatic reverence and protection, you've taken a small yet significant step towards totalitarianism. Symbols are inherently subjective - they don't inherently represent anything; their meaning is derived from how they are perceived or the significance attributed to them.

original: Holla so i saw troy tonight with my family...i was not impressed. I'm too tired to go way into specifics, but i do think it had potential. However, i think too much energy was spent on the set (which was magnificent) and not enough on creating a solidifying tone, theme, etc. It retold the story, but it was not particularly gripping, and i don't feel like i gained anything from watching it. The character development was rather weak. Additionally, i thought the score was poor, and was basically a knock-off of the gladiator. The gladiator used the background music of a moaning woman and it worked b/c it backed up and complemented a genuinely gripping narrative.
polished: I watched Troy with my family tonight, but unfortunately, it didn't leave a lasting impression on me. Although I'm too exhausted to delve into the details, I do believe the film had potential. However, I think the filmmakers invested too much in the set design, which was indeed magnificent, and not enough in establishing a cohesive tone and theme. The story was retold, but it lacked the gripping quality that would have made it memorable. I didn't feel like I gained any new insights from watching it, and the character development was somewhat lacking. Furthermore, I was underwhelmed by the score, which seemed to be a less effective imitation of the one from Gladiator. The use of a moaning woman's voice in the background music worked in Gladiator because it complemented a genuinely captivating narrative, which wasn't the case here.

original: Urllink lets all give a big hello to the newest atom/rdf/rss reader on the block, urllink pulpfiction 1.0 from urllink freshly squeezed software . It looks like it has a lot of native app goodness. It should be noted that it is not free or free, since that seems to be a 'hot topic' on the interweb again. You can try it for 15 days and then go back to something else, or pony up $25 if you like it. A feature that jumps out at me right away is how each post is its own entity, and can be moved around, stored, labeled, and even deleted. I could easily see how this would make some news tracker type people very happy. It imports and exports opml, as you might expect.
polished: Urllink introduces the latest atom/RDF/RSS reader, Urllink PulpFiction 1.0, from Urllink Freshly Squeezed Software. This application boasts a wealth of native app features. Notably, it is not free, a topic currently sparking debate on the internet. Users can try it for 15 days before deciding whether to revert to an alternative or purchase it for $25. A standout feature is the ability to treat each post as a distinct entity, allowing for easy movement, storage, labeling, and deletion. This functionality is likely to appeal to news tracker enthusiasts. As expected, the application supports OPML import and export.

original: Today... I miss my sister terribly - it just seems strange not to have her hanging around, irritating me (just joking...). Even though it was only for a week, she really made her presence felt, and i mean that in a good way. Just doing the scrapbook for our trtip to tasmania brings fond memories of a time past recently - last week in fact. Maybe it's just the thought that i won't see her for quite a while - with her going to bristol in sept/oct and all. She represented, on a deeper level, a link to my family back home. Oh how i miss them all. Tomorrow is the start of a new term. How did the holidays fly by so quickly?
polished: Today, I'm missing my sister terribly - it feels strange not having her around, even if she could be irritating at times (just kidding, of course). Although she was only here for a week, her presence was truly felt, and I mean that in the best possible way. Working on the scrapbook from our trip to Tasmania brings back fond memories of a time that feels like just yesterday - last week, to be exact. Perhaps it's the thought of not seeing her for a while, especially with her moving to Bristol in September or October, that's making me feel this way. On a deeper level, she represented a connection to my family back home, and I must admit, I'm missing them all dearly. Tomorrow marks the start of a new term, and I'm still wondering how the holidays flew by so quickly.

original: Ever have one of those days when you just don't know what the... What the... Anything? no? well then you should skip the rest of this because it won't make any sense to you. To those of you choosing to continue on i offer the following observation. ' sometimes i wish i'd been given the manual .' manuals, if done correctly at least, let you know: what things are for, what they can do, how they do the things they do, what happens if you push button x or y, what to do if things aren't doing what they're supposed to the phone number and email address of the omniscient guru who can solve every problem very useful information. Unfortunately i didn't get a manual with me.
polished: Ever have one of those days when you're completely at a loss for what to do or think? If not, you might want to skip the rest of this, as it may not resonate with you. However, for those who choose to continue, I'd like to share an observation. Sometimes I wish I had been given a manual for life. A well-written manual would provide clarity on what things are for, their capabilities, how they work, the consequences of certain actions, troubleshooting steps, and perhaps most importantly, contact information for an all-knowing expert who can resolve any issue. Unfortunately, I didn't receive a manual with my existence.

original: And there's nothing wrong with pcs -- if i were a full-bore gamer with time to do such a thing, i'd certainly have a pc system for the wealth of available games. Though except for a few unique products, that huge wall of games at compusa starts getting repetetive after a while -- at first i'm envious, then i start noticing that it's really just a lot of different flavors of the same soda...first-person shooters, mystery games, strategy games, simulations. There are so many variations of age of empires it becomes comical. Aoe -- with orcs! aoe -- with spaceships! aoe -- with fuzzy wombats! it's like the endless movie trailers that begin with the line: 'in a world...'
polished: There's nothing wrong with PCs - if I were an avid gamer with ample time, I'd definitely have a PC system for the vast array of available games. However, except for a few unique products, the extensive selection at CompUSA starts to feel repetitive after a while. Initially, I'm envious, but then I begin to notice that it's essentially a multitude of variations on the same theme - first-person shooters, mystery games, strategy games, and simulations. The numerous iterations of Age of Empires become almost comical. Age of Empires with orcs, with spaceships, or even with fuzzy wombats - it's reminiscent of movie trailers that start with the line, 'In a world...'

original: Jdasovic.nsf monday, december 11, 2000 to: all px market participants from: john yurkanin chief operating officer re: loss of continuity in px day ahead auction due to iso rule changes the emergency tariff filing by the california iso last friday has had a negative effect on the px day ahead auction market. The mixture of soft and hard caps results in a complete disconnect and unacceptable risk to all of our participants and will probably not provide the iso with its sought after reduction in real time energy sales and procurement. The overall effect will be that supply will still defer to the higher realized price opportunity the iso offers. The px is petitioning terry winter of the iso to immediately allow for adjustment bids on any submitted schedule at any price relevant.
polished: Jdasovic.nsf Monday, December 11, 2000 To: All PX Market Participants From: John Yurkanin, Chief Operating Officer Re: Loss of Continuity in PX Day-Ahead Auction due to ISO Rule Changes The emergency tariff filing by the California ISO last Friday has had a detrimental impact on the PX Day-Ahead Auction market. The combination of soft and hard caps has resulted in a complete disconnect, posing unacceptable risks to all our participants, and is unlikely to achieve the ISO's desired reduction in real-time energy sales and procurement. The overall effect will be that supply will continue to favor the higher realized price opportunity offered by the ISO. The PX is petitioning Terry Winter of the ISO to immediately permit adjustment bids on any submitted schedule at any relevant price.

original: Mark guzman 6-28-02.nsf just wanted to make sure you saw this from les rawson concerning grays harbor and willamette. -bill beginning immediately enron has purchased control area reserves service from bpa. The allows services to sell unit contingent energy as hourly firm since bpa is suppling reserves for up to 60 minutes. If grays harbor paper notifies rt of a unit derate or outage rt should notify bpa dispatch immediately and make the reduction in the schedule during the next ramp. For example should grays unit trip as 1333 rt would notify bpa and the sink that across the top of the hour for 1400 the schedule would be taken to zero for he 1400. The bottom line is that 60 minutes is the maximum time bpa will carry the schedule.
polished:
Mark Guzman 6-28-02.nsf - I wanted to ensure you saw this information from Les Rawson regarding Grays Harbor and Willamette. -Bill 

Beginning immediately, Enron has acquired control area reserves service from BPA. This enables services to sell unit contingent energy as hourly firm, as BPA will supply reserves for up to 60 minutes. If Grays Harbor Paper notifies RT of a unit derate or outage, RT should immediately notify BPA Dispatch and adjust the schedule accordingly during the next ramp. For instance, if Grays' unit trips at 1333, RT would notify BPA and adjust the schedule to zero for 1400, effective at the top of the hour. The key takeaway is that 60 minutes is the maximum time BPA will maintain the schedule.

original: Khyatt (non-privileged).pst el paso tests market for mainline expansion el paso natural gas apparently got the message when its last open season for 1.2 bcf/d of firm transportation capacity attracted bids for 14.4 bcf/d. The pipeline has announced an open season to test market interest in a mainline expansion and to satisfy regulatory concerns that something needs to be done to relieve the apparent capacity constraint at the california border. El paso has been under significant pressure from regulators and shippers to expand because of enormous demand and skyrocketing prices in california. In a jan. 3 letter to the pipeline, daniel m. Adamson, director of ferc's office of energy projects, urged el paso to consider modifying its line 2000 project to "assist the difficult situation" now facing the california gas market.
polished: Khyatt (non-privileged).pst El Paso Tests Market for Mainline Expansion. El Paso Natural Gas has apparently taken heed of the overwhelming response to its last open season for 1.2 Bcf/d of firm transportation capacity, which garnered bids for 14.4 Bcf/d. The pipeline has now announced an open season to gauge market interest in a mainline expansion, addressing regulatory concerns about the need to alleviate the apparent capacity constraint at the California border. El Paso has faced significant pressure from regulators and shippers to expand due to the enormous demand and skyrocketing prices in California. In a January 3 letter, Daniel M. Adamson, Director of FERC's Office of Energy Projects, urged El Paso to consider modifying its Line 2000 project to "assist the difficult situation" currently facing the California gas market.

Hello Kay, it's been a while since we last spoke, and I hope everything is going well. In November, Gregg Penman sent me two confidentiality agreements related to Enovate and asked me to forward any comments directly to you. I've finally had a chance to review them and have a few comments. The only proposed changes that require explanation are in paragraphs 1 and 3 of each agreement. These paragraphs contain typical provisions found in confidentiality agreements, where each party is evaluating a potential transaction.

original: Sscott5.nsf ahimsa (uh-him-sah) noun the principle of noninjury to living beings. [sanskrit ahimsa : a-, not + himsa, injury (from himsati, he injures).] "as my conception of ahimsa went on maturing, i became more vigilant about my thought and speech. The lines in the anthem: scatter her enemies and make them fall; confound their policies, frustrate their knavish tricks particularly jarred upon my sentiments of ahimsa." m.k. Gandhi, the story of my experiments with truth, 1927. Today is october 2, the day mohandas karamchand gandhi was born in the year 1869. Although a man born nearly two centuries ago may seem irrelevant to our age, his life and message remain remarkably applicable to our lives today.

original: Mgrigsb.nsf ? over the weekend, gov. Davis and senate polance made an informal agreement whereby senate polance has agreed to sponsor the socal mou bill. Polanco is a democrat and is currently suffering through a personal scandal and as a result, it is reported that his political career is essential dead. Polance is planning to run for mayor of los angeles rather than run for another senate term. ? the bill is expected to be introduced in the new extraordinary session, beginning today or tomorrow. The bill would first go to the senate energy committee. Sen. Bowen, the chair of the committee, strongly opposes the mou, so the bill is expected to remain in committee hearings for some time. The longer the bill is involved in committee politics and changes are made, the likelihood of a socal bankruptcy increases.
polished: Over the weekend, Governor Davis and Senator Polanco reached an informal agreement, whereby Senator Polanco has agreed to sponsor the SoCal MOU bill. As a Democrat currently embroiled in a personal scandal, Polanco's political career is reportedly all but over. He is instead planning to run for Mayor of Los Angeles rather than seeking another Senate term. The bill is expected to be introduced in the new extraordinary session, which begins today or tomorrow. It will first be referred to the Senate Energy Committee, chaired by Senator Bowen, who strongly opposes the MOU. As a result, the bill is likely to remain in committee hearings for some time, undergoing changes and negotiations. The longer the bill is mired in committee politics, the greater the likelihood of a SoCal bankruptcy.

original: Sshackle.nsf notice no. 00-338 october 3, 2000 memorandum to: all nymex and comex members from: neal l. Wolkoff, executive vice president date: october 3, 2000 re: notice of cftc approval of new nymex rule 6.40c: ("average price calculations by futures commission merchants") please be advised that the cftc has approved new nymex rule 6.40c ("average price calculations by futures commission merchants"), which is attached and is now in effect. New nymex rule 6.40c, which is consistent with a recent cftc "advisory," permits fcms, under certain conditions specified in the rule, to use their own internal, proprietary systems to generate average price ("ap") calculations when multiple prices are received on an order or series of orders.
polished: Sshackle.nsf Notice No. 00-338 October 3, 2000 Memorandum To: All NYMEX and COMEX Members From: Neal L. Wolkoff, Executive Vice President Date: October 3, 2000 Re: Notice of CFTC Approval of New NYMEX Rule 6.40C: ("Average Price Calculations by Futures Commission Merchants") Please be advised that the CFTC has approved and implemented new NYMEX Rule 6.40C, "Average Price Calculations by Futures Commission Merchants," which is attached. This rule, consistent with a recent CFTC advisory, allows Futures Commission Merchants (FCMs) to utilize their internal, proprietary systems for generating average price calculations under specified conditions when multiple prices are received for an order or series of orders.

original: Sshackle.nsf as of this week enrononline has just started offering us/canadian dollar swaps online. As part of my review in determining whether a counterparty can transact these products online i look at the financial trading agreement database to see if there are any restrictions indicated, check the master swap agreement, and i am also looking at any board resolutions we might have received when we got the master agreement executed. What i am finding is that in the old days when we asked for resolutions evidencing the authority to enter into the master agreement/derivative transactions frequently the resolutions do not allow the counterparies to enter into currency transactions. Since transacting these currency transactions with our energy customers is a new area of business for us i just wanted us all to be mindful to check these old resolutions and not to rely solely on the "restrictions" contained in lotus notes.
polished: Sshackle.nsf - As of this week, EnronOnline has begun offering US/Canadian dollar swaps online. In reviewing whether a counterparty can transact these products online, I examine the Financial Trading Agreement database for any indicated restrictions, review the Master Swap Agreement, and also consider any board resolutions received upon execution of the Master Agreement. Notably, I've found that in the past, when requesting resolutions to evidence authority to enter into the Master Agreement/derivative transactions, the resolutions often do not permit counterparties to engage in currency transactions. Given that transacting these currency transactions with our energy customers represents a new business area for us, I wanted to remind everyone to carefully review these older resolutions and not solely rely on the 'restrictions' contained in Lotus Notes.

original: Dhyvl.nsf dave, i will be glad to generate the form of transaction agreement; however, i have a number of questions. 1. Relationship of delivery point and the use of interruptible transport on northwest pipeline. Is the transport upstream or downstream of the delivery point? if downstream, why isn't it being contracted for by eweb. 2. What volume is being sold each day. You use the term dcq and you also talk about a 20% tolerance above or below the estimated quantity. Normally their would be no tolerance with a dcq transaction. 3. Is this envisioned to be a requirements transaction. Is the price the same for volumes in excess of the estimated quantity up to an additional 20%.
polished:
Dhyvl.nsf Dave, I'd be happy to generate the form of transaction agreement; however, I have a few questions that need clarification. 

1. Could you please specify the relationship between the delivery point and the use of interruptible transport on the Northwest Pipeline? Is the transport located upstream or downstream of the delivery point? If it's downstream, why isn't it being contracted for by eWeb?

2. What is the daily volume being sold? You've mentioned DCQ and also referenced a 20% tolerance above or below the estimated quantity. Typically, a DCQ transaction wouldn't involve a tolerance.

3. Is this intended to be a requirements transaction? Additionally, is the price the same for volumes exceeding the estimated quantity, up to an additional 20%?

original: Jdasovic.nsf the spreadsheet below gives the implicit commodity based on the effective date of four different rates for the same rate schedule (schedule dr). The rate schedule effective august 2000 through september 2000 yields a much larger commodity charge because sdg&e customers will receive a lump sum reimbursement from sdg&e over those two months. Sdg&e customers will expect lower electric bills. Assuming that the lump sum reimbursement is not included in the implicit energy component, the average for june 2000 through january 2001 is 6.2 cts and the implicit commodity average from february 2001 through december 2001 is 7.3 cts. The average implicit commodity from june 2000 through december 2001 is 6.9 cts for deliveries starting september 1, 2000, the average would still be 6.9 cts.
polished: The spreadsheet below illustrates the implicit commodity charge based on the effective date of four different rates for the same rate schedule (Schedule DR). Notably, the rate schedule in effect from August 2000 through September 2000 results in a significantly higher commodity charge, as SDG&E customers will receive a lump sum reimbursement from SDG&E during these two months, leading to lower expected electric bills. Excluding the lump sum reimbursement from the implicit energy component, the average implicit commodity charge from June 2000 through January 2001 is 6.2 cents, while the average from February 2001 through December 2001 is 7.3 cents. Overall, the average implicit commodity charge from June 2000 through December 2001 remains at 6.9 cents, which would still be the case for deliveries starting on September 1, 2000.

original: Tdonoho (non-privileged).pst this has been a tough couple of weeks. I hope that these daily communications on new developments are helping you understand what's happening with our company. Here's a rundown of events from last week: we executed a commitment letter with jpmorgan and salomon smith barney that will provide us with additional secured credit lines worth $1 billion. Our northern natural gas company and transwestern pipeline company will support these assets. We now have received a total of $4 billion in credit lines, which we will use to pay off short-term commercial debt and maintain liquidity. Our board of directors elected a new member to the board - william powers, jr., the dean of the university of texas school of law in austin, texas.
polished: T. Donoho (non-privileged).pst - It has been a challenging couple of weeks. I hope these daily updates on new developments are helping you stay informed about the latest happenings within our company. Here's a summary of key events from last week: we successfully executed a commitment letter with JPMorgan and Salomon Smith Barney, securing additional credit lines worth $1 billion. Our Northern Natural Gas Company and Transwestern Pipeline Company will provide support for these assets. We have now secured a total of $4 billion in credit lines, which will be utilized to settle short-term commercial debt and maintain liquidity. Furthermore, our Board of Directors has elected a new member, William Powers, Jr., the Dean of the University of Texas School of Law in Austin, Texas.

original: Skean.nsf i am attaching the ferc order and staff recommendations. The order provides for $69 million in "potential" refunds (either pay up or provide cost justification). Enron was not named as one of the 13 overcharging parties, but pge was ($3.18 million). It's not over yet, though. The order deals only with jan 01 and promises further orders regarding dec 00 and benchmark prices through april 01. The prices used to determine refunds were fairly high ($273/mwh based on gas prices, emissions costs and an assumed heat rate of over 16000). With respect to sales to california, we have concluded at least one short term sale and have talked with cal dept of water resources about longer term deals, but we were still struggling with credit issues, last i heard.
polished: I am attaching the FERC order and staff recommendations. The order provides for $69 million in potential refunds, which can be settled either by payment or by providing cost justification. Although Enron was not named as one of the 13 parties found to be overcharging, PG&E was, with a total of $3.18 million. However, this matter is not yet resolved. The order only addresses January 2001 and promises further orders regarding December 2000 and benchmark prices through April 2001. The prices used to determine refunds were relatively high, at $273/MWh, based on gas prices, emissions costs, and an assumed heat rate of over 16,000. Regarding sales to California, we have successfully concluded at least one short-term sale and have discussed longer-term deals with the California Department of Water Resources, but we were still grappling with credit issues, as of my last update.
