However, some guns are overpowered, and the matchmaking can be unfair at times, but it's not as bad as Battlefield 3's matchmaking. As a newbie, I was often matched with higher-level players who seemed almost invincible, as shooting them in the face had little effect.

original: Who wouldn't want to wear a fez? :d this puzzle platforming game stars a little guy with a fez who goes around collecting little bits to form a cube and navigating through a fairly large branching map. This game is quite amusing and running through it to complete the game was quite a bit of fun. ^_^ it can become semi-frustrating if you want to get all the cubes and achievements though. To get all the cubes you'll need to crack codes that you'll have to decipher. These can take a few seconds or frustrate you into looking into a guide (*raises hand* i gave up. -_-). The guide, 'a complete guide to fez!!!'
polished: Who wouldn't want to wear a fez? This puzzle platforming game stars a little guy with a fez who collects small pieces to form a cube and navigates through a large, branching map. The game is quite amusing, and completing it was a lot of fun. However, it can become semi-frustrating if you aim to collect all the cubes and achievements. To do so, you'll need to crack codes that require deciphering, which can take anywhere from a few seconds to being frustrating enough to consult a guide. The guide, 'A Complete Guide to Fez!!!', may come in handy, as I personally found myself giving up and seeking help.

original: It's not hard for me to see why other people like this game, but it wasn't for me. For one thing i have a vive and i'm much more interested in playing room sized games with the controllers. Beyond that, the game is initially awe inspiring in the scale of its universe, but i also felt that same scale was a hinderence to my enjoyment. The learning curve and the amount of time to do anything interesting at the beginning were both too large for me. Perhaps if i were more patient and had more time for gaming this would be compelling to me. But i don't have either and there are plenty more vr games i'd rather spend my time on.
polished: I can appreciate why others enjoy this game, but it didn't resonate with me. As a Vive owner, I'm more inclined towards room-scale experiences that utilize controllers. While the game's vast universe is initially awe-inspiring, I found its scale to be a hindrance to my overall enjoyment. The learning curve and time required to accomplish anything meaningful at the beginning were too steep for me. If I had more patience and gaming time, I might find this game compelling. However, with limited time and numerous other VR games vying for my attention, I'd rather focus on those.

original: Hands down my favorite first person shooter of all time. Run and gun rambos need not apply. Recoil and ballistics are realistic. Single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle caliber weapons almost always result in death unless it just grazes you. Rounds drop over distance and short, controlled bursts are required if you wish to remain on target. There is no magical ammunition pool. If you reload half-way through your magazine all the time then you will have a pouch full of half full mags. You can't run forever. If you sprint for a while your aim will suffer as you gasp heavily until you have caught your breath. Rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill to steady your aim. Accuracy suffers when standing.
polished: Hands down, my all-time favorite first-person shooter. This game isn't for run-and-gun Rambo types. Recoil and ballistics are remarkably realistic, with single hits to the chest, neck, or head from rifle-caliber weapons almost always resulting in death, unless the shot merely grazes you. Rounds drop significantly over distance, and short, controlled bursts are necessary to stay on target. There's no infinite ammunition pool; if you constantly reload mid-magazine, you'll end up with a pouch full of partially used magazines. Endless sprinting isn't an option either, as prolonged running will leave you gasping for breath, severely impacting your aim until you've caught your breath. To steady your aim, rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a windowsill. Accuracy also suffers when standing, making it essential to adapt your shooting stance.

original: Let me start off by saying i did not purchase eu when it first came out and that i got it on sale which included ew so i never experienced the issues that some people claim to have had with that game. I loved that game however, it was unforgiving in the early stages but rewarding when you did things right. As for xcom2 i love it, the game plays pretty well for me on medium and i am running a gtx560 with 2gb of vram. At first the game set it to high and it was running a bit sluggishly but not to the point of being unplayable but when i dropped it down to medium it smoothed on out. Not sure if i am just lucky when it comes to having issues with games or what but it seems that most of the negative reviews sound like they are coming from some really entitled people.
polished: I'd like to start by saying that I didn't purchase EU when it first launched, instead opting to buy it on sale, which included EW. As a result, I never experienced the issues that some players claim to have had with the game. Nevertheless, I thoroughly enjoyed it, finding it to be challenging in the early stages but incredibly rewarding when executed correctly. Moving on to XCOM 2, I must say that I love the game, and it runs relatively smoothly for me on medium settings, despite my somewhat outdated hardware - a GTX 560 with 2GB of VRAM. Initially, the game defaulted to high settings, resulting in some minor performance issues, but dropping it down to medium resolved the problem. I'm not sure if I'm just fortunate when it comes to avoiding game-related issues or if there's another factor at play, but many of the negative reviews seem to be coming from individuals with unrealistic expectations.

original: +rpg levelling +wide-variety of ship types +physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missles +easy-to-learn resource management +dark humored -grind intensive (if under utilizing the civvy station types) -sub-par ai teammates -low variety of equipment types -low variety of levelling skills (that is, no branching) listen, this game is fun as hell. Despite my minuses up there, there is still some variety and strategy to be had. It starts off fast and still really picks up. Even though there's a low variety of equipment, it still feels like there's always another ship to unlock or skill to level up. The best way to increase the life of this game is the mods. Fight for universe is easily the star, but big fight for beef is also very good.
polished: This game boasts an engaging RPG levelling system, a diverse array of ship types, and physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles. The resource management is easy to grasp, and the dark humor adds to the experience. However, it can be grind-intensive if the civilian station types are underutilized, and the AI teammates are somewhat subpar. Additionally, the variety of equipment types and levelling skills is limited, with no branching options. Despite these drawbacks, the game remains incredibly enjoyable, offering a good balance of variety and strategy. The pace is fast from the start and continues to pick up, with a constant sense of progression as new ships and skills are unlocked. To further extend the game's lifespan, mods are a great option, with Fight for Universe and Big Fight for Beef being standout additions.

original: World leaders gather to face uncertainty more than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe are arriving in the swiss mountain resort davos for the annual world economic forum (wef). For five days, they will discuss issues ranging from china's economic power to iraq's future after this sunday's elections. Uk prime minister tony blair and south african president thabo mbeki are among the more than 20 government leaders and heads of state leaders attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protests against the wef are expected to be muted. Anti-globalisation campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. The brazilian city of porto alegre will host the rival world social forum, timed to run in parallel with the wef's ritzier event in davos.
polished: More than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the world are converging on the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF), where they will tackle pressing issues such as China's growing economic influence and Iraq's future in the wake of this Sunday's elections. Over the course of five days, the gathering will be attended by more than 20 government leaders and heads of state, including UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki. Notably, protests against the WEF are expected to be subdued this year, with anti-globalisation campaigners having cancelled a planned demonstration. Meanwhile, the Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, which will run concurrently with the WEF's high-profile event in Davos.

original: Deadline nears for fiat-gm deal fiat and general motors (gm) have until midnight on 1 february to settle a disagreement over a potential takeover. The deadline marks the point at which fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to gm, part of an alliance agreed in 2000. Gm, whose own european operations are losing money, no longer wants to own the unprofitable fiat unit. Reports of deadlocked talks sent fiat shares down 1.2% on tuesday, after monday's 4% gain on hopes of a payoff. The us firm is thought to be offering about $2bn (£1.06bn) to extricate itself from the arrangement. It has argued the deal was voided by fiat's decision to sell off fiat's finance arm and halve gm's stake via a capital-raising effort. The 2000 deal resulted from a race between gm and daimlerchrysler to ally with fiat.
polished: The deadline for Fiat and General Motors (GM) to resolve their dispute over a potential takeover is nearing, with the two companies having until midnight on 1 February to reach an agreement. This deadline marks the point at which Fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to GM, as part of their alliance formed in 2000. However, GM, which is struggling with losses in its European operations, no longer wishes to acquire the unprofitable Fiat unit. Following reports of stalled negotiations, Fiat's shares fell 1.2% on Tuesday, after a 4% gain on Monday due to hopes of a settlement. GM is reportedly offering around $2 billion (£1.06 billion) to extricate itself from the arrangement, arguing that the deal was nullified by Fiat's decision to sell its finance arm and reduce GM's stake through a capital-raising effort. The 2000 agreement was the result of a competitive bid between GM and DaimlerChrysler to form an alliance with Fiat.

original: Cardinal criticises iraq war cost billions of pounds spent on conflict in iraq and in the middle east should have been used to reduce poverty, cardinal cormac murphy-o'connor has said. The head of the catholic church in england and wales made the comments on bbc radio 4 and will re-iterate his stance in his christmas midnight mass. The cardinal used a christmas message to denounce the war in iraq as a "terrible" waste of money. He and the archbishop of canterbury have both spoken out about the war. Speaking on bbc radio 4's thought for the day slot, he criticised the fact that "billions" have been spent on war, instead of being used to bring people "out of dire poverty and malnourishment and disease". The cardinal said 2005 should be the year for campaigning to "make history poverty".
polished: Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has criticised the billions of pounds spent on the Iraq war and conflicts in the Middle East, stating that the funds could have been better utilised to alleviate poverty. The head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales expressed his views on BBC Radio 4 and is expected to reiterate his stance during his Christmas midnight mass. In a Christmas message, the cardinal denounced the Iraq war as a "terrible" waste of resources, echoing sentiments previously shared by the Archbishop of Canterbury. During his appearance on BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day, he lamented the fact that vast sums have been spent on war, rather than being invested in initiatives to lift people out of dire poverty, malnourishment, and disease. The cardinal urged that 2005 should be a year of concerted effort to "make history poverty".

original: British stars denied major oscars british hopes of winning major oscars were dashed as uk stars failed to win acting and directing prizes. Despite three nominations, mike leigh's vera drake failed to take the director or screenplay awards and there was no prize for star imelda staunton. Kate winslet also lost to best actress hilary swank, while clive owen and sophie okonedo failed to win best supporting actor awards. The uk's andrea arnold won the short film award for her gritty drama wasp. Arnold, who presented children's television shows number 73 and motormouth in the 1980s, said it was "totally overwhelming" to win. Wasp tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, beating films by fellow uk nominees gary mckendry and ashvin kumar.
polished: British stars miss out on major Oscars, as UK hopes of securing top prizes were dashed when British talent failed to win in the acting and directing categories. Despite receiving three nominations, Mike Leigh's Vera Drake was unsuccessful in securing the director or screenplay awards, and its star, Imelda Staunton, also went home empty-handed. Kate Winslet lost out to Best Actress winner Hilary Swank, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo were unsuccessful in their bids for Best Supporting Actor awards. However, the UK's Andrea Arnold did secure a win, taking home the Short Film award for her gritty drama Wasp. Arnold, a former presenter of children's television shows Number 73 and Motormouth in the 1980s, described her win as "totally overwhelming". Wasp, which tells the story of a single mother struggling to make ends meet, beat out films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

original: Halloween writer debra hill dies screenwriter and producer debra hill, best known for her work on the 70s horror classic halloween, has died in los angeles aged 54. Hill, who had been suffering from cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, which starred jamie lee curtis as a babysitter terrorised by a psychopath. Directed by john carpenter, it made over $60m (£31.3m) worldwide - a record for independent film at that time. Hill also worked with carpenter on escape from new york and the fog. Born in new jersey, hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way through the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before she began collaborating with carpenter. She was regarded by many as a pioneering woman in film, taking on jobs in the 70s that were more commonly taken by men.
polished: Debra Hill, the renowned screenwriter and producer behind the 1970s horror classic Halloween, has passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film that catapulted Jamie Lee Curtis to fame as a babysitter stalked by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, the film grossed over $60 million (£31.3 million) worldwide, setting a record for independent films at the time. Hill's collaboration with Carpenter extended to other notable projects, including Escape from New York and The Fog. Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and gradually rose through the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before teaming up with Carpenter. As a trailblazing woman in film, Hill broke ground in the 1970s by taking on roles traditionally dominated by men.

original: Broadband fuels online expression fast web access is encouraging more people to express themselves online, research suggests. A quarter of broadband users in britain regularly upload content and have personal sites, according to a report by uk think-tank demos. It said that having an always-on, fast connection is changing the way people use the internet. More than five million households in the uk have broadband and that number is growing fast. The demos report looked at the impact of broadband on people's net habits. It found that more than half of those with broadband logged on to the web before breakfast. One in five even admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the web. More significantly, argues the report, broadband is encouraging people to take a more active role online.
polished: Broadband is driving online expression, with fast web access encouraging more people to express themselves online, research indicates. A quarter of Britain's broadband users regularly upload content and maintain personal websites, according to a report by UK think-tank Demos. The report suggests that having a constant, fast connection is transforming the way people utilize the internet. Over five million UK households have adopted broadband, with this number increasing rapidly. The Demos report examined the impact of broadband on internet usage habits. It discovered that more than half of broadband users log on to the web before breakfast, while one in five admitted to browsing the web in the middle of the night. More notably, the report argues, broadband is prompting people to take a more active role online.

original: Yukos heading back to us courts russian oil and gas company yukos is due in a us court on thursday as it continues to fight for its survival. The firm is in the process of being broken up by russian authorities in order to pay a $27bn (£14bn) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the us, hoping to use international business law to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, yuganskneftegas. The unit was however sold for $9.4bn to state oil firm rosneft but only after the state auction had been disrupted. Yukos lawyers now say the auction violated us bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to go after any company that buys its assets, using all and every legal means.
polished: Russian oil and gas company Yukos is set to appear in a US court on Thursday as it continues its fight for survival. The firm is currently being dismantled by Russian authorities to settle a $27 billion (£14 billion) tax bill. In an attempt to utilize international business law to block the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas, Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the US. However, the unit was sold to state-owned oil firm Rosneft for $9.4 billion, following a disrupted state auction. Yukos' lawyers now argue that the auction breached US bankruptcy law. The company and its primary shareholders have pledged to pursue any company that acquires its assets, employing all available legal means.

original: Voters flock to blog awards site voting is under way for the annual bloggies which recognise the best web blogs - online spaces where people publish their thoughts - of the year. Nominations were announced on sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that the website was temporarily closed because of too many visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, from the top regional blog, to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a huge year, with a top us dictionary naming "blog" word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and says that more than 12,000 are added daily. A blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to us research think-tank pew internet and american life, but less than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months.
polished: Voters flock to blog awards site as voting gets underway for the annual Bloggies, which recognize the best web blogs - online spaces where individuals publish their thoughts - of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but the official site experienced a temporary closure due to an overwhelming influx of visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, ranging from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a remarkable year, with a top US dictionary naming "blog" the word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks approximately six million blogs and reports that over 12,000 are added daily. According to US research think-tank Pew Internet and American Life, a new blog is created every 5.8 seconds, although less than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months.

original: Chinese dam firm 'defies beijing' the china three gorges project corp is refusing to obey a government order to stop construction of one of its giant dams, the chinese state press has said. The builder of the three gorges dam is continuing work on the sister xiluodu dam, said the beijing news. The xiluodu dam is one of 30 such large-scale construction projects called to a halt because of a lack of proper environmental checks. The beijing news said the company may instead choose to pay a fine. The firm has also ignored orders to stop construction at two of its other projects - the three gorges underground power plant and the three gorges project electrical power supply plant. So far, only 22 of the 30 construction projects targeted by china's state environmental protection agency (sepa) for having not carried out mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with its shutdown order.
polished: Chinese dam firm 'defies Beijing' as the China Three Gorges Project Corp refuses to comply with a government order to halt construction of one of its massive dams, according to the Chinese state press. The builder of the Three Gorges Dam is proceeding with work on the sister Xiluodu Dam, reports the Beijing News. The Xiluodu Dam is among 30 large-scale construction projects ordered to stop due to inadequate environmental checks. The Beijing News suggests that the company may opt to pay a fine instead. Furthermore, the firm has disregarded orders to cease construction at two other projects - the Three Gorges underground power plant and the Three Gorges project electrical power supply plant. To date, only 22 of the 30 construction projects targeted by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for failing to conduct mandatory environmental impact assessments have adhered to the shutdown order.

original: Man city 0-2 man utd manchester united reduced chelsea's premiership lead to nine points after a scrappy victory over manchester city. Wayne rooney met gary neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which went in via a deflection off richard dunne, to put united ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate dunne hooked a volley over david james' head and into his own net. Steve mcmanaman wasted city's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes united had looked unlikely to earn the win they needed to maintain any chance of catching chelsea in the title race. Their approach play was more laboured than patient and they managed to fashion just one chance - a paul scholes header over the bar.
polished: Manchester United reduced Chelsea's Premiership lead to nine points with a scrappy 2-0 victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney met Gary Neville's cross at the near post with a low shot that deflected off Richard Dunne, putting United ahead. Seven minutes later, Dunne unfortunately hooked a volley over David James' head and into his own net. Steve McManaman squandered City's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes, United seemed unlikely to secure the win needed to maintain any chance of catching Chelsea in the title race, with their approach play appearing laboured rather than patient, and they managed to create just one chance - a Paul Scholes header over the bar.

original: Wales 'must learn health lessons' the new health minister for wales says there are lessons to learn from england in tackling waiting lists. Dr brian gibbons, on his first full day in the job after jane hutt was sacked, admitted "big challenges" but insisted the "essentials" were in place. But both plaid cymru and the liberal democrats said dr gibbons needed to change policy. Meanwhile ms hutt defended her record, saying waiting times and lists were "only 10% of the health agenda. Dr gibbons, who was a gp in blaengwynfi, in the upper afan valley, before becoming am for aberavon, said nhs staff wanted a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform". One of the biggest problems which had faced ms hutt during her five-and-a-half years as the assembly's first health minister was the length of waiting lists in wales.
polished: Wales 'must learn health lessons' from England, says new Health Minister. Dr Brian Gibbons, on his first full day in the job following Jane Hutt's dismissal, acknowledged "big challenges" but maintained that the "essentials" were in place. However, both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats argued that Dr Gibbons needed to change policy. Meanwhile, Ms Hutt defended her record, stating that waiting times and lists comprised "only 10% of the health agenda." Dr Gibbons, a former GP in Blaengwynfi, Upper Afan Valley, and AM for Aberavon, said NHS staff desired a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform." One of the major issues that had plagued Ms Hutt during her five-and-a-half-year tenure as the assembly's first Health Minister was the lengthy waiting lists in Wales.

original: Ferguson hails man utd's resolve manchester united's alex ferguson has praised his players' gutsy performance in the 1-0 win at aston villa. "that was our hardest away game of the season and it was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end with lots of good passing," said the old trafford boss. "we showed lots of character and guts and we weren't going to lose. "i look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while arsenal and chelsea have yet to come and villa may have some players back when they do." ferguson also hailed senior stars ryan giggs and roy keane, who came off the bench for the injured john o'shea. "roy came on and brought a bit of composure to the midfield which we needed and which no other player has got.
polished: Manchester United's Alex Ferguson has commended his team's resolute display in their 1-0 victory at Aston Villa. "That was undoubtedly our toughest away fixture of the season, and it was a thrilling match with end-to-end action and plenty of impressive passing," the Old Trafford boss noted. "We demonstrated immense character and determination, and we were resolute in our refusal to lose. I view that fixture as a significant test, one that we've successfully navigated, whereas Arsenal and Chelsea still have to come, and Villa may have some key players back by then." Ferguson also praised senior players Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who replaced the injured John O'Shea. "Roy's introduction brought a much-needed sense of composure to our midfield, a quality that he uniquely possesses.

original: Singer's film to show at festival a documentary which takes a candid look at the life of chart-topping singer george michael will be shown at this year's berlin film festival. A different story will screen in the panorama section of the festival, which runs from 10-20 february. It features the singer talking about both his career and his personal life, from his days in wham! through to more recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 february. Director southan morris and executive producer andy stephens will also attend the festival. The 93 minute film will see michael discussing his early days in wham! along with his later career, including his legal battles with record label sony and his stance against the iraq war and american politics.
polished: A documentary offering a candid glimpse into the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will premiere at this year's Berlin Film Festival. 'A Different Story' is set to screen in the festival's Panorama section, which takes place from 10-20 February. The film features Michael reflecting on his career and personal life, spanning his early days in Wham! to more recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 February, joined by director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens. The 93-minute documentary sees Michael discussing his Wham! days, his later career, including his high-profile legal battles with Sony, and his outspoken stance against the Iraq War and American politics.

original: Downloads enter us singles chart digital music downloads are being included in the main us singles chart for the first time. Billboard's hot 100 chart now incorporates data from sales of music downloads, previously only assigned to a separate download chart. Green day's boulevard of broken dreams is currently number two in billboard's pop chart, and tops its digital chart. Download sales are due to be incorporated into the uk singles chart later this year. Digital sales in the us are already used to compile billboard's hot digital sales chart. They will now be tallied with sales of physical singles and airplay information to make up its new hot 100 chart. Its second new chart - the pop 100 - also combines airplay, digital and physical sales but confines its airplay information to us radio stations which play chart music.
polished: Downloads enter the US singles chart as digital music downloads are incorporated into the main US singles chart for the first time. Billboard's revamped Hot 100 chart now combines data from sales of music downloads, previously tracked on a separate download chart, with physical singles sales and airplay information. Green Day's 'Boulevard of Broken Dreams' currently holds the number two spot on Billboard's pop chart and tops the digital chart. The UK singles chart is also set to include download sales later this year. In the US, digital sales are already used to compile Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart, and will now be merged with physical singles sales and airplay data to form the new Hot 100 chart. Additionally, Billboard's new Pop 100 chart combines airplay, digital, and physical sales, but limits its airplay information to US radio stations that play chart music.

original: Anti-spam laws bite spammer hard the net's self-declared spam king is seeking bankruptcy protection. Scott richter, the man behind optinrealbig.com and billions of junk mail messages, said lawsuits had forced the company into chapter 11. Optinrealbig was fighting several legal battles, most notably against microsoft, which is pushing for millions of dollars in damages. The company said filing for chapter 11 would help it try to resolve its legal problems but still keep trading. Listed as the third biggest spammer in the world by junk mail watchdog spamhaus, optinrealbig was sued in december 2003 for sending mail messages that violated anti-spam laws. The lawsuit was brought by microsoft and new york attorney general eliot spitzer who alleged that mr richter and his accomplices sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised net addresses in 35 countries.
polished: The self-declared "spam king" of the internet is seeking bankruptcy protection after being hit hard by anti-spam laws. Scott Richter, the mastermind behind OptinRealBig.com, which is responsible for sending billions of junk mail messages, has stated that lawsuits have forced the company to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy. OptinRealBig.com was embroiled in several high-profile legal battles, most notably with Microsoft, which is seeking millions of dollars in damages. By filing for Chapter 11, the company hopes to resolve its legal issues while continuing to operate. Ranked as the world's third-largest spammer by Spamhaus, a junk mail watchdog, OptinRealBig.com was sued in December 2003 for violating anti-spam laws. The lawsuit, brought by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, alleged that Richter and his associates sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised internet addresses in 35 countries.

original: Arnesen denies rift with santini tottenham sporting director frank arnesen has denied that coach jacques santini resigned because of a clash of personalities at white hart lane. There had been newspaper speculation that santini had felt undermined by arnesen's role at the club. "it is absolutely not true," arnesen told bbc radio five live. "there is only one thing that made him resign and that is his own personal problems. "he has talked to me recently and said this matter is absolutely for himself." arnesen said he was unable to throw any light onto the problems that caused santini to quit after just 13 games in charge. He added: "jacques has never gone into exactly what it was. But i trust him in that; you have to accept it. I think we should respect it.
polished: Tottenham Sporting Director Frank Arnesen has denied speculation of a rift with former coach Jacques Santini, insisting that Santini's resignation was due to personal problems rather than a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. Arnesen dismissed the claims, stating, "It is absolutely not true." He revealed that Santini had confided in him about the issue, saying, "He has spoken to me recently and said this matter is absolutely personal." Arnesen refused to elaborate on the nature of Santini's problems, which led to his departure after just 13 games in charge. "Jacques has never disclosed the exact details, but I trust him and respect his decision," he added, emphasizing the need to respect Santini's privacy.

original: Ireland surge past scots ireland maintained their six nations grand slam ambitions with an impressive victory over scotland at murrayfield. Hugo southwell's try gave the scots an early 8-0 lead but scores from locks malcolm o'kelly and paul o'connell put the visitors in command by half-time. A third try from wing denis hickie and third penalty from ronan o'gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon petrie scored a second try for scotland but late scores from john hayes and gavin duffy sealed victory. After two hard-earned away victories, eddie o'sullivan' side can now look forward to welcoming england to lansdowne road in a fortnight. Scotland will try to give their coach matt williams a first six nations victory when italy come to edinburgh, but they again struggled to turn pressure into points.
polished: Ireland surged past Scotland, maintaining their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with an impressive victory at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's try gave the Scots an early 8-0 lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in command by half-time. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and a third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed the victory. Following two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to hosting England at Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will attempt to give their coach Matt Williams his first Six Nations victory when Italy visit Edinburgh, but they again struggled to convert pressure into points.

original: Economy focus for election battle britain's economic future will be at the heart of labour's poll campaign, chancellor gordon brown has said. He was speaking after cabinet members held their last meeting at no 10 before the expected election announcement. He said voters would recognise that labour had brought stability and growth, and would continue to do so. Meanwhile the tories outlined their plans to tackle "yob culture" and the lib dems gave more details about their proposals to replace council tax. Earlier the archbishop of canterbury wrote to all three parties urging them not to fight the election by exploiting people's fears. In an open letter, he called on them not to turn the election into a competition about who can most effectively frighten voters about terrorism, asylum, and crime.
polished: Britain's economic future will be at the forefront of Labour's election campaign, according to Chancellor Gordon Brown. Speaking after the final Cabinet meeting at No 10 before the anticipated election announcement, he stated that voters would acknowledge Labour's role in bringing stability and growth, and would continue to do so. In the meantime, the Tories have outlined their strategy to tackle "yob culture", while the Liberal Democrats have provided further details on their proposals to replace council tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury penned an open letter to the three parties, urging them to refrain from exploiting people's fears during the election campaign. He cautioned against turning the election into a competition over who can most effectively instil fear in voters regarding terrorism, asylum, and crime.

original: Brizzel to run aaa's in sheffield ballymena sprinter paul brizzel will be among eight of ireland's european indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's aaa's championships. Corkman mark carroll confirmed in midweek that he would join cragg in the european championships. original: Robinson wants dual code success england rugby union captain jason robinson has targeted dual code success over australia on saturday. Robinson, a former rugby league international before switching codes in 2000, leads england against australia at twickenham at 1430 gmt. And at 1815 gmt, great britain's rugby league team take on australia in the final of the tri-nations tournament. "beating the aussies in both games would be a massive achievement, especially for league," said robinson. England have the chance to seal their third autumn international victory after successive wins over canada and south africa, as well as gaining revenge for june's 51-15 hammering by the wallabies. original: Warning over tsunami aid website net users are being told to avoid a scam website that claims to collect cash on behalf of tsunami victims. The site looks plausible because it uses an old version of the official disasters emergency committee webpage. However, dec has no connection with the fake site and says it has contacted the police about it. The site is just the latest in a long list of scams that try to cash in on the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is contained in a spam e-mail that is currently circulating. The message's subject line reads "urgent tsunami earthquake appeal" and its text bears all the poor grammar and bad spelling that characterises many other phishing attempts.
polished: Net users are being warned to avoid a scam website that claims to collect donations on behalf of tsunami victims. The site appears legitimate as it utilizes an outdated version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee webpage. However, the DEC has no affiliation with the fake site and has reported it to the authorities. This website is the latest in a series of scams attempting to exploit the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is being circulated through a spam email with the subject line "Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal," which is characterized by poor grammar and spelling typical of phishing attempts.

original: Iraq to invite phone licence bids iraq is to invite bids for two telephone licences, saying it wants to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. Bids have been invited from local, arab and foreign companies, iraq's ministry of communications said. The winner will work in partnership with the iraqi telecommunications and post company (itpc). The firms will install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax and internet services. The ministry said that it wanted to increase iraq's "very low telephone service penetration rate from about 4.5% today to about 25% within 10 years." it also hopes to develop a "highly visible and changeable telecommunication sector". Details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the ministry's website on 9 february. It also is planning a road-show for investors in amman, jordan.
polished: Iraq to Invite Phone Licence Bids. Iraq is set to invite bids for two telephone licences, with the aim of significantly boosting nationwide coverage over the next decade. The country's Ministry of Communications has invited bids from local, Arab, and foreign companies. The winning bidder will work in partnership with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC) to install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry aims to increase Iraq's telephone service penetration rate from approximately 4.5% to around 25% within 10 years. It also hopes to develop a highly visible and dynamic telecommunications sector. Details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the ministry's website on 9 February, and a road-show for investors is planned in Amman, Jordan.

original: More women turn to net security older people and women are increasingly taking charge of protecting home computers against malicious net attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women buying programs to protect pcs from virus, spam and spyware attacks rose by 11.2% each year between 2002 and 2004. The study, for net security firm preventon, shows that security messages are reaching a diversity of surfers. It is thought that 40% of those buying home net security programs are retired. For the last three years, that has gone up by an average of 13.2%. But more retired women (53%) were buying security software than retired men. The research reflects the changing stereotype and demographics of web users, as well as growing awareness of the greater risks that high-speed broadband net connections can pose to surfers.
polished: More women are taking charge of home computer security, with older individuals and women increasingly protecting their systems against malicious online attacks, a two-year study reveals. Between 2002 and 2004, the number of women purchasing programs to safeguard PCs against viruses, spam, and spyware rose by 11.2% annually. The study, conducted for net security firm Preventon, indicates that security messages are resonating with a diverse range of internet users. It is estimated that 40% of those buying home internet security programs are retirees, with this figure increasing by an average of 13.2% over the past three years. Notably, more retired women (53%) are purchasing security software than retired men. The research reflects shifting stereotypes and demographics among web users, as well as growing awareness of the heightened risks associated with high-speed broadband internet connections.

original: Podcasts mark rise of diy radio an apple ipod or other digital music players can hold anything up to 10,000 songs, which is a lot of space to fill. But more and more ipod owners are filling that space with audio content created by an unpredictable assortment of producers. It is called "podcasting" and its strongest proponent is former mtv host and vj (video jockey) adam curry. Podcasting takes its name from the apple ipod, although you do not need an ipod to create one or to listen to a podcast. A podcast is basically an internet-based radio show which podcasters create, usually in the comfort of their own home. They need only a microphone, a pc, and some editing software. They then upload their shows to the internet and others can download and listen to them, all for free.
polished: Podcasts mark the rise of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or other digital music players can hold up to 10,000 songs, a vast amount of space to fill. However, an increasing number of iPod owners are utilizing this space to store audio content created by a diverse range of producers. This phenomenon is known as "podcasting," with former MTV host and VJ Adam Curry being its most prominent advocate. Although podcasting takes its name from the Apple iPod, it is not necessary to own an iPod to create or listen to a podcast. Essentially, a podcast is an internet-based radio show produced by individuals, often from the comfort of their own homes, using a microphone, a PC, and editing software. The shows are then uploaded to the internet, allowing others to download and listen to them at no cost.

original: Levy takes whitbread novel prize orange prize winner andrea levy has seen her book small island win the whitbread novel of the year award. She is now favourite to win the overall prize after beating booker winner alan hollinghurst's the line of beauty. Geraldine mccaughrean has picked up the children's fiction award for the third time for not the end of the world. All the category winners go through to compete for the whitbread book of the year title, which carries with it a £25,000 prize. A panel of judges including sir trevor mcdonald, actor hugh grant and writer joanne harris will meet up on 25 january to decide the overall winner, with the announcement being made later that evening. Bookmaker william hill has placed london-based levy's novel as the 6/4 favourite to win.

A panel of judges, including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris, will convene on 25 January to determine the overall winner, with the announcement to be made later that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has positioned Levy's novel as the 6/4 favourite to win.

original: Yukos seeks court action on sale yukos will return to a us court on wednesday to seek sanctions against baikal finance group, the little-known firm which has bought its main asset. Yukos has said it will sue baikal and others involved in the sale of yuganskneftegas for $20bn in damages. Yukos' us lawyers will attempt to have baikal assets frozen after the russian government ignored a us court order last week blocking the sale. Baikal's background and its motives for buying the unit are still unclear. Russian newspapers have claimed that baikal - which bought the yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4bn (261bn roubles, £4.8bn) on sunday at a state provoked auction - has strong links with surgutneftegas, russia's fourth-biggest oil producer.
polished: Yukos to pursue court action over sale. original: Hearts 2-1 livingston hearts wrapped up their scottish cup quarter-final tie against livingston with two goals in the first 10 minutes. Lee miller scored inside the opening 60 seconds, heading over colin meldrum and into the net from a jamie mcallister free kick. Mcallister himself scored the second when he met saul mikoliunas' cross at the back post to put the game beyond the visitors. Craig easton headed in a controversial goal after an hour but hearts held on. The opening goal came after gus bahoken had clumsily fouled miller 35 yards from goal. Mcallister floated the free kick into the livi box and miller outjumped the static visiting defence to loop his header from 10 yards over meldrum. With just 10 minutes on the clock, the home side doubled their lead. Mikoliunas sprinted down the right, crossed to the back post where mcallister raced in to head past meldrum.
polished: Hearts sealed their Scottish Cup quarter-final tie against Livingston with a 2-1 victory, thanks to two goals within the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller opened the scoring inside the first minute, heading a Jamie McAllister free kick over Colin Meldrum and into the net. McAllister himself doubled the lead when he met Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post, effectively putting the game out of the visitors' reach. Craig Easton scored a contentious goal for Livingston after an hour, but Hearts held on for the win. The opening goal came after Gus Bahoken clumsily fouled Miller 35 yards from goal, prompting McAllister to float a free kick into the Livingston box. Miller outjumped the static visiting defence to loop his header from 10 yards over Meldrum. With just 10 minutes on the clock, Hearts doubled their advantage. Mikoliunas sprinted down the right flank, delivering a cross to the back post where McAllister timed his run perfectly to head past Meldrum.

original: Sun offers processing by the hour sun microsystems has launched a pay-as-you-go service which will allow customers requiring huge computing power to rent it by the hour. Sun grid costs users $1 (53p) for an hour's worth of processing and storage power on systems maintained by sun. So-called grid computing is the latest buzz phrase in a company which believes that computing capacity is as important a commodity as hardware and software. Sun likened grid computing to the development of electricity. The system could mature in the same way utilities such as electricity and water have developed, said sun's chief operating officer jonathan schwartz. "why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?" he asked in a webcast launching sun's quarterly network computing event in california.
polished: Sun Microsystems has introduced a pay-as-you-go service, allowing customers to rent massive computing power by the hour. The Sun Grid service costs users $1 per hour for processing and storage power on systems maintained by Sun, equivalent to 53p. Grid computing, the latest buzz phrase, is a concept where computing capacity is viewed as a commodity on par with hardware and software. Sun draws parallels between grid computing and the evolution of electricity. According to Jonathan Schwartz, Sun's Chief Operating Officer, the system has the potential to mature similarly to utilities like electricity and water. "Why build your own grid when you can use ours for just a dollar an hour?" he asked during a webcast launching Sun's quarterly Network Computing event in California.

original: Jamieson issues warning to bigots scotland's justice minister has warned bigoted soccer fans that she wants to hit them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy jamieson said exclusion orders are one of a series of measures being considered in the scottish executive campaign against sectarianism. She praised celtic and rangers for their work in tackling the problem. However, the minister said stopping sectarian abuse associated with old firm matches is a key objective. Ms jamieson was speaking ahead of the third round scottish cup clash between the glasgow clubs at parkhead on sunday. The sectarianism long associated with sections of the support from both clubs has become a significant target for the executive. Last week ms jamieson and first minister jack mcconnell met supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the issue.
polished: Scotland's Justice Minister, Cathy Jamieson, has issued a stern warning to bigoted soccer fans, stating that she intends to take a tough stance by banning them from matches, effectively hitting them "where it hurts most". As part of the Scottish Executive's campaign against sectarianism, exclusion orders are being considered as one of several measures. Jamieson commended Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in addressing the issue, but emphasized that eradicating sectarian abuse associated with Old Firm matches remains a top priority. Her comments came ahead of the highly anticipated Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday. The Scottish Executive has made tackling sectarianism, long linked to certain sections of support from both clubs, a key objective. Recently, Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell met with supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the matter.

original: Uk debut for kevin spacey movie hollywood stars kevin spacey and kate bosworth attended the british premiere of new film, beyond the sea, in london's leicester square on thursday. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed and starred in the film, inspired by the life of 1950s croooner bobby darin. polished:
UK Debut for Kevin Spacey Movie 

Hollywood stars Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth attended the British premiere of the new film, Beyond the Sea, in London's Leicester Square on Thursday. Spacey, 45, who wrote, directed, and starred in the film, drew inspiration from the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This is my tribute to someone I think was a remarkable talent," said Spacey, who, as Darin, performs all 18 songs on the film soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife, real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. "I knew absolutely nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan," said Bosworth, who attended the premiere with her British boyfriend, Orlando Bloom.

original: Home phones face unclear future the fixed line phone in your home could soon be an endangered species. Research by handset maker nokia shows that more and more people are using their mobile phone for every call they make or take. According to the study, more than 45 million people in the uk, germany, us and south korea now only use a mobile. It showed that people keep their fixed line phone because call charges are lower, but most of those questioned said the future was definitely mobile. The nokia-sponsored research showed that mobiles and fixed phones were used for different purposes. Home phones were used for longer calls but conversations on mobiles tended to be shorter, between mobiles and to friends. In the uk 69% of those questioned said they turned to their fixed phone because it was still cheaper to use than a mobile.
polished: The home phone faces an uncertain future, as the fixed line phone in your home may soon become an endangered species. Research conducted by handset maker Nokia reveals that an increasing number of people are relying on their mobile phones for all their calls. According to the study, over 45 million individuals in the UK, Germany, the US, and South Korea now exclusively use mobile phones. Although people retain their fixed line phones due to lower call charges, the majority of those surveyed believe that the future of communication lies with mobile phones. The Nokia-sponsored research found that mobile and fixed phones serve different purposes, with home phones being used for longer conversations, while mobile calls tend to be shorter, often between friends. In the UK, 69% of respondents cited cost as the primary reason for using their fixed phone, as it remains cheaper than using a mobile.

original: Melzer shocks agassi second seed andre agassi suffered a comprehensive defeat by jurgen melzer in the quarter-finals of the sap open. Agassi was often bamboozled by the austrian's drop shots in san jose, losing 6-3 6-1. Defending champion and top seed andy roddick rallied to beat sweden's thomas enqvist 3-6 7-6 (8-6) 7-5. But unseeded cyril saulnier beat the fourth seed vincent spadea 6-2 6-4 and tommy haas overcame eighth seed max mirnyi 6-7 (2-7) 7-6 (7-3) 6-2. Melzer has now beaten agassi in two of their three meetings. "i had a good game plan and i executed it perfectly," he said. "it's always tough to come out to play andre. "i didn't want him to play his game. He makes you run like a dog all over the court."
polished: Melzer stuns Agassi as second seed Andre Agassi suffered a crushing defeat at the hands of Jurgen Melzer in the SAP Open quarter-finals. Agassi was frequently outmaneuvered by the Austrian's clever drop shots in San Jose, ultimately losing 6-3, 6-1. Defending champion and top seed Andy Roddick staged a comeback to defeat Sweden's Thomas Enqvist 3-6, 7-6 (8-6), 7-5. However, unseeded Cyril Saulnier upset fourth seed Vincent Spadea 6-2, 6-4, and Tommy Haas overcame eighth seed Max Mirnyi 6-7 (2-7), 7-6 (7-3), 6-2. Melzer has now beaten Agassi in two of their three encounters. "I had a solid game plan and executed it flawlessly," he said. "It's always challenging to face Andre. I didn't want him to dictate the game. He forces you to cover the entire court.

original: Mps tout lords replacement plan a group of mps has tried to raise the pressure on tony blair over reform to the house of lords by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. The cross-party group has unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber in which 70% of members would be elected. Mps and peers have failed to agree on reform since 1999 when 600 hereditaries lost their seats. The group says it can win support for removing the last 92 hereditaries. The government postponed plans to remove the remaining hereditary peers because they said they were unlikely to succeed after opposition in the lords. Tony blair has argued. There needs to be consensus on reforms. There have been suggestions there will be proposals for changing at least the powers of the lords in labour's manifesto.
polished: A cross-party group of MPs has intensified pressure on Tony Blair to reform the House of Lords by releasing a detailed proposal for change. The group has unveiled a draft bill that outlines a smaller second chamber, where 70% of its members would be elected. Since 1999, when 600 hereditary peers lost their seats, MPs and peers have been unable to reach an agreement on reform. The group is confident that it can garner support for the removal of the remaining 92 hereditary peers. The government had previously postponed plans to abolish the remaining hereditary peers, citing concerns that the move would be unsuccessful due to opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair has emphasized the need for consensus on reforms, and there are indications that Labour's manifesto may include proposals to alter the powers of the Lords.

original: Disappointed scott in solid start allan scott is confident of winning a medal at next week's european indoor championships after a solid debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the jose m cagigal memorial meeting in madrid. "it was definitely a learning curve and i certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the east kilbride athlete. The race was won by felipe vivancos, who equalled the spanish record. Sweden's robert kronberg was second, with haiti's dudley dorival in third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his run in the final. He won his heat in 7.64secs but ran 0.04secs slower in his first iaaf indoor grand prix circuit final.
polished: Allan Scott is confident of securing a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships following a solid international debut. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Jose M Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid. "It was definitely a learning experience, and I haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete. Felipe Vivancos won the event, equalling the Spanish record, while Sweden's Robert Kronberg took second place and Haiti's Dudley Dorival finished third. Although Scott won his heat in 7.64 seconds, he was slightly disappointed with his final run, which was 0.04 seconds slower.

original: Us woman sues over cartridges a us woman is suing hewlett packard (hp), saying its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a certain date. The unnamed woman from georgia says that a chip inside the cartridge tells the printer that it needs re-filling even when it does not. The lawsuit seeks to represent anyone in the us who has purchased an hp inkjet printer since february 2001. Hp, the world's biggest printer firm, declined to comment on the lawsuit. Hp ink cartridges use a chip technology to sense when they are low on ink and advise the user to make a change. But the suit claims the chips also shut down the cartridges at a predetermined date regardless of whether they are empty.
polished: A US woman is suing Hewlett Packard (HP), alleging that its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a predetermined date. The unnamed woman from Georgia claims that a chip inside the cartridge informs the printer that it needs refilling, even when it still contains ink. The lawsuit aims to represent all US residents who have purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's largest printer manufacturer, has declined to comment on the lawsuit. While HP ink cartridges utilize chip technology to detect low ink levels and prompt users to make a change, the suit alleges that these chips also shut down the cartridges at a predetermined date, regardless of their actual ink levels.

original: Virgin radio offers 3g broadcast uk broadcaster virgin radio says it will become the first station in the world to offer radio via 3g mobiles. The radio station, in partnership with technology firm sydus, will broadcast on selected 2g and high-speed 3g networks. Later this year listeners will be able to download software from the virgin website which enables the service. James cridland, head of new media at virgin radio, said: "it places radio at the heart of the 3g revolution." virgin radio will be the first station made available followed by two digital stations, virgin radio classic rock and virgin radio groove. Mr cridland said: "this application will enable anyone, anywhere to listen to virgin radio simply with the phone in their pocket.
polished: Virgin Radio is set to become the world's first station to offer radio broadcasts via 3G mobiles. In partnership with technology firm Sydus, the UK broadcaster will transmit on select 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year, listeners will be able to download software from the Virgin website, enabling them to access the service. According to James Cridland, Head of New Media at Virgin Radio, "this innovation places radio at the forefront of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will be the first station available, followed by two digital stations: Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Cridland added, "this application will allow anyone, anywhere to tune into Virgin Radio using just their mobile phone.

original: Spirit awards hail sideways the comedy sideways has dominated this year's independent spirit awards, winning all six of the awards for which it was nominated. It was named best film while alexander payne won best director and best screenplay, along with writing partner jim taylor. It also won acting awards for stars paul giamatti, thomas haden church and virginia madsen. Sideways is tipped to do well at sunday's oscars, with five nominations. The awards, now in their 20th year, are given to films made outside the traditional studio system, and are traditionally held the day before the oscars. Other winners included catalina sandino moreno, who took best actress for her role as a drug smuggler in the colombian drama maria full of grace. Moreno is also nominated for best actress at the oscars. The best first screenplay award went to joshua marston for maria full of grace.
polished: The comedy "Sideways" dominated this year's Independent Spirit Awards, winning all six awards for which it was nominated. The movie also secured acting awards for its stars, Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen. With five Oscar nominations, "Sideways" is expected to perform well at Sunday's ceremony. Now in their 20th year, the Independent Spirit Awards honor films produced outside the traditional studio system and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars. Other notable winners included Catalina Sandino Moreno, who won Best Actress for her portrayal of a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama "Maria Full of Grace," a role that has also earned her an Oscar nomination for Best Actress. Joshua Marston received the Best First Screenplay award for "Maria Full of Grace.

original: Prince crowned 'top music earner' prince earned more than any other pop star in 2004, beating artists such madonna and elton john in us magazine rolling stone's annual list. The singer banked $56.5m (£30.4m) from concerts, album and publishing sales with his musicology tour and album. He kept madonna in second place, as she earned $54.9m (£29.5m) while embarking on her global re-invention tour. Veterans simon and garfunkel were in 10th place, their comeback tour helping them earn $24.9m (£13.4m) last year. "prince returned to centre stage after a decade in the commercial wilderness," the magazine reported. The singer's 2004 tour took $90.3m (£48.5m) in ticket sales and he sold 1.9 million copies of his latest album musicology.

original: Blue beat u2 to top france honour irish band u2 have been honoured at france's biggest music awards, but were beaten to a prize by boy band blue. Collecting his band's award from model naomi campbell at the cannes ceremony, u2 frontman bono said in french: "i'm not from this country but i'll make a little confession to you - it's at the cote d'azur i feel at home."
polished: Irish band U2 received a special achievement prize at France's biggest music awards, but were narrowly beaten to the international group award by British boy band Blue. polished: Wal-mart has launched a counterattack against its critics, with two major US companies initiating advertising campaigns to "set the record straight" about their products and corporate practices. original: Tories outlining policing plans local communities would be asked to go to the polls to elect their own area police commissioner, under plans unveiled by the conservatives. Party leader michael howard said the new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities. He said the new office would not supersede the job of a chief constable. The lib dems said the plan could let extreme groups run policing, while labour criticised "extravagant" tory promises on policing. Responding to the plans, the chairman of the police federation of england and wales, which represents rank and file officers, said it was essential operational independence was retained. Jan berry said: "it is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every time an election approaches. "these plans could result in those with extreme political views dictating what actually happens on the ground," she warned.
polished: The Tories have outlined policing plans that would see local communities elect their own area police commissioner, as unveiled by the Conservatives. Party leader Michael Howard stated that the new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities, while emphasizing that it would not supersede the position of a chief constable. The Liberal Democrats expressed concerns that the plan could allow extreme groups to control policing, whereas Labour criticized the "extravagant" Tory promises on policing. In response to the plans, Jan Berry, chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, which represents rank-and-file officers, stressed the importance of retaining operational independence. She warned, "Policing is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every time an election approaches. These plans risk allowing those with extreme political views to dictate what happens on the ground.

original: At a glance: tory health checks the uk' opposition conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the plan: people coming to live and work in britain from outside the eu. If they plan to stay six months or more and are from a country with lots of tb, they would have to have a chest x-ray and further tests if appropriate. All people from outside the european union who want to stay a year or more will have to undergo a full medical. Tuberculosis, hepatitis b and hiv. A positive test for tb would automatically mean visa applications being turned down. All other conditions would be dealt with on a case by case basis.
polished: At a glance: Tory health checks. The UK's opposition Conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the plan: Immigrants coming to live and work in Britain from outside the EU will be subject to health checks. Those planning to stay six months or more and originating from countries with high TB prevalence will be required to undergo a chest x-ray, with further tests if necessary. All non-EU nationals seeking to stay a year or more will be required to undergo a comprehensive medical examination, which will include tests for tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive TB test result will automatically lead to visa application rejection, while other conditions will be assessed on a case-by-case basis.

original: Paris promise raises welsh hopes has there been a better six nations match than saturday's epic in paris? and can the welsh revival continue all the way to a first grand slam since 1978? those are the two questions occupying not just wales supporters but rugby fans as a whole after a scintillating display in paris. Welsh legend mervyn davies, a member of two of three grand slam-winning sides of the 1970s, hailed it as "one of the great performances of the past three decades". Martyn williams, wales' two-try scorer on the day, called it "one of the most surreal games i have ever played in". A crestfallen france coach, bernard laporte, simply observed: "there was a french half and there was a welsh half".
polished: The Paris promise has rekindled Welsh hopes - is Saturday's epic encounter in the French capital the most thrilling Six Nations match in recent memory? Meanwhile, a crestfallen France coach, Bernard Laporte, succinctly observed: "There was a French half and a Welsh half.

original: Cabinet anger at brown cash raid ministers are unhappy about plans to use whitehall cash to keep council tax bills down, local government minister nick raynsford has acknowledged. Gordon brown reallocated £512m from central to local government budgets in his pre-budget report on thursday. Mr raynsford said he had held some "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers over the plans. But he said local governments had to deliver good services without big council tax rises. The central government cash is part of a £1bn package to help local authorities in england keep next year's council tax rises below 5%, in what is likely to be a general election year. Mr raynsford said nearly all central government departments had an interest in well run local authorities.
polished: Cabinet ministers have expressed anger over plans to utilize Whitehall funds to keep council tax bills low, a move acknowledged by Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford. In his pre-budget report on Thursday, Gordon Brown reallocated £512m from central to local government budgets. Mr. Raynsford revealed that he had engaged in "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers regarding the plans. However, he emphasized that local governments must provide quality services without substantial council tax increases. The central government funding is part of a £1bn package aimed at assisting local authorities in England in limiting next year's council tax rises to below 5%, a crucial consideration in a likely general election year. According to Mr. Raynsford, nearly all central government departments have a vested interest in the effective operation of local authorities.

original: Israeli club look to africa four african players, including zimbabwe goalkeeper energy murambadoro, are all ready to play for israeli club hapoel bnei sakhnin in the uefa cup. Bnei sakhnin are the first arab side ever to play in european competition and will play english premiership side newcastle united in the first round. Warriors' goalkeeper murambadoro, who made a name for himself at the african nations cup finals in tunisia, helped bnei sakhnin overcome albania's partizani tirana 6-1 in the previous round. Murambadoro moved to israel recently after a brief stint with south african club hellenic. The club won the israeli cup final last season and are based in sakhnin, which is near haifa. The club have a strong ethic and are high profile promoters of peace and co-operation within israel.
polished: Israeli club looks to Africa for talent, with four African players, including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, set to play for Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin in the UEFA Cup. As the first Arab side to compete in European competition, Bnei Sakhnin will face English Premiership side Newcastle United in the first round. Following a brief stint with South African club Hellenic, Murambadoro recently relocated to Israel. Bnei Sakhnin, based in Sakhnin near Haifa, won the Israeli Cup final last season and is known for promoting peace and co-operation within Israel, with a strong ethos to match.

original: New drink limit 'would cut toll' more lives than previously thought could be saved by cutting drink-drive limits by a third, a report says. University college london research claims cutting the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would save 65 lives a year. The findings are being published by the parliamentary advisory council for transport safety as mps are due to vote on the government's road safety bill. The bill includes changes to speeding fines but not to the drink-drive limit. The research, carried out by transport expert professor richard allsop, says cutting the limit would also lead to 230 fewer serious injuries on the uk's roads compared with 2003. He estimates that this would save the country £119m a year. A previous estimate, contained in a 1998 department of transport document, suggested such a move could save 50 lives a year.
polished: A new report suggests that lowering the drink-drive limit could save more lives than initially thought. Research by University College London claims that reducing the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would result in 65 lives saved annually. The findings, published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety, come as MPs prepare to vote on the government's Road Safety Bill, which includes changes to speeding fines but not the drink-drive limit. According to transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, who conducted the research, lowering the limit would also lead to 230 fewer serious injuries on UK roads each year, compared to 2003. This reduction is estimated to save the country £119m annually. A previous estimate from a 1998 Department of Transport document suggested that such a move could save around 50 lives per year.

original: This paper presents a millimeter-scale cmos 64$\times$64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1$\times$1 $\mu m^2$ diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512$\times$512 $\mu m^2$. Instead of sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline. This obviates the need for using power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype asic is fabricated in tsmc 65 nm lp cmos process and consumes the average static power of 0.535 mw under 1.2 v analog and digital power supply. The functionality of the whole system is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 mev proton beam setting.
polished: This paper presents a millimeter-scale CMOS 64×64 single charged particle radiation detector system designed for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1×1 μm^2 diode measures the energy deposited by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512×512 μm^2. Unlike traditional approaches that sense the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time required for the voltage to return to its baseline, thereby eliminating the need for power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC fabricated in the TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process consumes an average static power of 0.535 mW under a 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The system's functionality has been successfully verified in a clinical setting using a 67.5 MeV proton beam.

original: Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (avs) has been shown to reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that avs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that aims to incentivize avs to seek centrally controlled system optimal (so) routing by saving on tolls while user equilibrium (ue) seeking avs and human-driven vehicles (hvs) are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, in which dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, whereas the lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model considering mixed fleet of avs and hvs.
polished: Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been demonstrated to mitigate the adverse effects of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that AVs would readily accept external control by a central agency is unrealistic. This paper proposes a joint routing and pricing control scheme that incentivizes AVs to adopt centrally controlled system-optimal (SO) routing by offering toll savings, while user equilibrium (UE) seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HDVs) are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, where dynamic tolls are optimized at the upper level, and the lower level employs a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model that accounts for a mixed fleet of AVs and HDVs.

original: Optomechanics and electromechanics have made it possible to prepare macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, in quadrature squeezed states, and in entangled states of motion. In addition to coaxing ever larger and more tangible objects into a regime of quantum behavior, this new capability has encouraged ideas of using mechanical oscillators in the processing and communication of quantum information and as precision force sensors operating beyond the standard quantum limit. But the effectively linear interaction between motion and light or electricity precludes access to the broader class of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Indeed, early optomechanical proposals noted the possibility to escape this restriction by creating strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. Although there have been experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, these have not yet accessed nonclassical states of motion.
polished: Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, quadrature squeezed states, and entangled states of motion. This capability has not only facilitated the extension of quantum behavior to larger, more tangible objects, but also sparked ideas for utilizing mechanical oscillators in quantum information processing and communication, as well as precision force sensing beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the effectively linear interaction between motion and light or electricity limits access to a broader range of quantum states of motion, such as cat states and energy squeezed states. Notably, early optomechanical proposals suggested that creating strong quadratic coupling between motion and light could overcome this limitation.
