polished: Weight pruning is widely recognized as a straightforward and effective method for eliminating redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), resulting in accelerated performance across various platforms. However, most pruning techniques involve trade-offs between model accuracy and regularity, leading to compromised inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration capabilities. To address this issue, we propose a novel sparsity dimension, pattern-based sparsity, which combines pattern and connectivity sparsity to achieve both high accuracy and hardware friendliness. By carefully designing patterns, our pruning approach consistently achieves unprecedented accuracy enhancement and improved feature extraction capabilities across different DNN structures and datasets. Furthermore, our pattern-aware pruning framework enables simultaneous pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pattern and connectivity pruning, and weight training. Our approach, based on the new pattern-based sparsity, seamlessly integrates with compiler optimization, enabling highly efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.

original: Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that differs considerably from a treated group is vulnerable to bias from historical events that have different effects on the groups. Constructing a more closely matched control group by matching a subset of the overall control group to the treated group may result in less bias. We study this phenomenon in simulation studies. We study the effect of mountaintop removal mining (mrm) on mortality using a difference-in-differences analysis that makes use of the increase in mrm following the 1990 clean air act amendments. For a difference-in-differences analysis of the effect of mrm on mortality, we constructed a more closely matched control group and found a 95\% confidence interval that contains substantial adverse effects along with no effect and small beneficial effects.
polished: Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that significantly diverges from a treated group is susceptible to bias from historical events that have disparate effects on the groups. Creating a more closely matched control group by matching a subset of the overall control group to the treated group can potentially mitigate this bias. We investigate this phenomenon through simulation studies. We examine the impact of mountaintop removal mining (mrm) on mortality using a difference-in-differences analysis that leverages the increase in mrm following the 1990 Clean Air Act amendments. For a difference-in-differences analysis of the effect of mrm on mortality, we constructed a more closely matched control group and obtained a 95% confidence interval that encompasses substantial adverse effects, as well as no effect and small beneficial effects.

original: When constructing models to summarize clinical data to be used for simulations, it is good practice to evaluate the models for their capacity to reproduce the data. This can be done by means of visual predictive checks (vpc), which consist of (1) several reproductions of the original study by simulation from the model under evaluation, (2) calculating estimates of interest for each simulated study and (3) comparing the distribution of those estimates with the estimate from the original study. This procedure is a generic method that is straightforward to apply, in general. Here we consider the application of the method to time to event data and consider the special case when a time-varying covariate is not known or cannot be approximated after event time.
polished: When constructing models to summarize clinical data for simulation purposes, it is a good practice to assess their ability to reproduce the data. This can be achieved through visual predictive checks (VPCs), which involve (1) simulating multiple reproductions of the original study from the model under evaluation, (2) calculating estimates of interest for each simulated study, and (3) comparing the distribution of these estimates with the estimate from the original study. This procedure is a widely applicable, straightforward method. Here, we explore its application to time-to-event data, with a focus on the special case where a time-varying covariate is unknown or cannot be approximated after the event time.

original: Novel concepts, perspectives and challenges in measuring and controlling an open quantum system via sequential schemes are shown. We discuss how similar protocols, relying both on repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, can allow to: (i) confine and protect quantum dynamics from decoherence in accordance with the zeno physics. (ii) analytically predict the probability that a quantum system is transferred into a target quantum state by means of stochastic sequential measurements. (iii) optimally reconstruct the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing in the frequency domain the filter functions driving the designed quantum-sensor. The achievement of these tasks will enhance our capability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, thus bringing advances to quantum science and technologies.
polished: Novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling open quantum systems through sequential schemes are presented. We explore how similar protocols, leveraging both repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, can facilitate: (i) confinement and protection of quantum dynamics from decoherence, in line with Zeno physics principles. (ii) analytical prediction of the probability of transferring a quantum system into a target state via stochastic sequential measurements. (iii) optimal reconstruction of the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing filter functions in the frequency domain, thereby enhancing the performance of designed quantum sensors. The accomplishment of these tasks will significantly enhance our ability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, driving advancements in quantum science and technologies.

original: Palms sweaty, heart racing, stomach in knots. You can't cry for help. Not only is your throat too tight to breathe, but it'd be so embarrassing. No, you aren't being stalked by a monster, you're speaking in public, a fate some deem worse than death.see, when you're dead, you feel nothing; at a podium, you feel stage fright. But at some point we've all had to communicate in front of people, so you have to try and overcome it.to start, understand what stage fright is. Humans, social animals that we are, are wired to worry about reputation. Public speaking can threaten it. Before a speech, you fret, "what if people think i'm awful and i'm an idiot?"
polished: Palms sweaty, heart racing, stomach in knots - you're paralyzed with fear. You can't cry out for help, not only because your throat is constricted, but also because it would be mortifying. You're not being pursued by a monster, but rather, you're facing the daunting task of public speaking, a prospect some consider worse than death. When you're deceased, you feel nothing, but at the podium, you're consumed by stage fright. However, since we've all had to communicate in front of an audience at some point, it's essential to try and overcome this anxiety. To begin, it's crucial to understand what stage fright is. As social creatures, humans are inherently wired to worry about their reputation, and public speaking can pose a significant threat to it. Before a speech, your mind is flooded with doubts: "What if people think I'm terrible and I'm an idiot?

original: I can't think of anyone who just has one interest in life, and that's all they want to do for the rest of their life. [the way we work]around 15 percent of american workers don't have traditional full-time jobs. They're half-time, part-time, contract workers or temps. The term "side hustle" just seems to fit with this ethos where people are putting together a few different things to make a living.the word "side hustle" has its roots in popular african american newspapers. In the 1920s, these papers used the word "hustle" to refer to some kind of scam. By the 1950s, they were using "side hustle" to refer to legitimate work, too. A side hustle is a little different than a second job. A second job is about necessity.
polished: It's rare to find someone with a single interest in life that they're content to pursue for the rest of their days. In the US, around 15 percent of workers don't have traditional full-time jobs, instead opting for part-time, contract, or temporary work arrangements. The term "side hustle" resonates with this modern ethos, where individuals piece together multiple pursuits to make a living. The phrase "side hustle" has its origins in popular African American newspapers from the 1920s, where "hustle" initially referred to a scam. By the 1950s, however, "side hustle" was also used to describe legitimate work. A side hustle differs from a second job, which is often driven by necessity.

original: Two twin domes, two radically opposed design cultures. One is made of thousands of steel parts, the other of a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other organic. One is imposed on the environment, the other creates it. One is designed for nature, the other is designed by her.michelangelo said that when he looked at raw marble, he saw a figure struggling to be free. The chisel was michelangelo's only tool. But living things are not chiseled. They grow. And in our smallest units of life, our cells, we carry all the information that's required for every other cell to function and to replicate.tools also have consequences. At least since the industrial revolution, the world of design has been dominated by the rigors of manufacturing and mass production.
polished: Two twin domes, two vastly different design cultures. One is composed of thousands of steel components, while the other is crafted from a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other organic. One imposes itself on the environment, while the other harmonizes with it. One is designed in response to nature, the other is designed by nature itself. Michelangelo once said that when he gazed at raw marble, he envisioned a figure yearning to be set free. The chisel was his sole tool. However, living organisms are not shaped by chisels; they grow and evolve. Within our cells, the smallest units of life, lies the information necessary for every other cell to function and replicate. Tools, too, have far-reaching consequences. Since the Industrial Revolution, the world of design has been largely governed by the demands of manufacturing and mass production.

original: Hello. My name is simone. You know how people tell you if you get nervous when onstage, picture people in the audience naked? like it's this thing that's supposed to make you feel better. But i was thinking — picturing all of you naked in 2018 feels kind of weird and wrong. Like, we're working really hard on moving past stuff like that, so we need a new method of dealing with if you get nervous onstage. And i realized that what i'd really like is that i can look at you as much as you're looking at me — just to even things out a little bit. So if i had way more eyeballs, then we'd all be really comfortable, right?
polished: Hello, my name is Simone. You're probably familiar with the advice that if you get nervous on stage, you should imagine the audience naked. It's supposed to be a calming technique, but to be honest, picturing everyone naked in 2018 feels somewhat awkward and outdated. We're striving to move beyond that kind of thinking, so I think it's time for a new approach to managing stage nerves. What I'd really like is to be able to look at you all as much as you're looking at me – just to create a sense of balance. If I had multiple eyeballs, it would level the playing field and make everyone feel more at ease, wouldn't it?

original: "to do two things at once is to do neither." it's a great smackdown of multitasking, isn't it, often attributed to the roman writer publilius syrus, although you know how these things are, he probably never said it. What i'm interested in, though, is — is it true? i mean, it's obviously true for emailing at the dinner table or texting while driving or possibly for live tweeting at ted talk, as well. But i'd like to argue that for an important kind of activity, doing two things at once — or three or even four — is exactly what we should be aiming for.look no further than albert einstein. In 1905, he published four remarkable scientific papers.
polished: To do two things at once is to do neither." This phrase, often attributed to the Roman writer Publilius Syrus, serves as a scathing critique of multitasking. Although its origin is uncertain, the statement's validity is what truly matters. While it's undoubtedly true for activities like emailing during dinner, texting while driving, or live tweeting at a TED talk, I'd like to propose that for certain pursuits, doing multiple things simultaneously is precisely what we should strive for. A notable example is Albert Einstein, who in 1905, published four groundbreaking scientific papers, showcasing the potential benefits of concurrent productivity.

original: I know this is going to sound strange, but i think robots can inspire us to be better humans. See, i grew up in bethlehem, pennsylvania, the home of bethlehem steel. My father was an engineer, and when i was growing up, he would teach me how things worked. We would build projects together, like model rockets and slot cars. Here's the go-kart that we built together. That's me behind the wheel, with my sister and my best friend at the time. And one day, he came home, when i was about 10 years old, and at the dinner table, he announced that for our next project, we were going to build ... A robot.a robot.
polished: I know this may sound unusual, but I believe robots can inspire us to become better humans. Growing up in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, the former home of Bethlehem Steel, had a profound impact on me. My father, an engineer, would often explain how things worked, and we would collaborate on various projects, such as building model rockets and slot cars. One notable project was this go-kart that we built together - I'm behind the wheel, accompanied by my sister and best friend at the time. When I was around 10 years old, my father came home and announced at the dinner table that our next project would be something entirely new: a robot.

original: Sustainability represents the what, the where and the how of what is caught. The who and the why are what's important to me. I want to know the people behind my dinner choices. I want to know how i impact them. I want to know how they impact me. I want to know why they fish. I want to know how they rely on the water's bounty for their living. Understanding all of this enables us to shift our perception of seafood away from a commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. It allows for us to celebrate the seafood that we're also so fortunate to eat.so what do we call this? i think we call it restorative seafood. Where sustainability is the capacity to endure and maintain, restorative is the ability to replenish and progress.
polished: Sustainability encompasses the what, where, and how of seafood production. However, it's the who and why that truly matter to me. I'm interested in learning about the people behind my dinner choices, understanding how my decisions impact them, and how they, in turn, impact me. I want to know their motivations for fishing and how they rely on the ocean's resources for their livelihood. By gaining this insight, we can shift our perspective on seafood from a commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. This allows us to appreciate the seafood we're fortunate to eat, while also promoting a more positive relationship with the environment. I believe this approach can be described as restorative seafood. While sustainability focuses on endurance and maintenance, restorative seafood is about replenishing and progressing, ultimately creating a more sustainable future.

original: The starving orphan seeking a second helping of gruel. The spinster wasting away in her tattered wedding dress. The stone-hearted miser plagued by the ghost of christmas past. More than a century after his death, these remain recognizable figures from the work of charles dickens. So striking is his body of work that it gave rise to its own adjective. But what are the features of dickens's writing that make it so special?dickens’s fiction brims with anticipation through brooding settings, plot twists, and mysteries. These features of his work kept his audience wanting more. When first published, his stories were serialized, meaning they were released a few chapters at a time in affordable literary journals and only later reprinted as books.
polished: The starving orphan craving a second helping of gruel, the spinster wasting away in her tattered wedding dress, and the stone-hearted miser haunted by the ghost of Christmas past remain instantly recognizable figures from the works of Charles Dickens, more than a century after his passing. His body of work is so striking that it has given rise to its own distinctive adjective. But what are the key features of Dickens's writing that make it so enduringly special? Dickens's fiction is characterized by an atmosphere of anticipation, fostered through brooding settings, unexpected plot twists, and intriguing mysteries. These elements kept his audience eagerly anticipating the next installment. Initially, his stories were serialized, released in affordable literary journals a few chapters at a time, before being reprinted in book form.

original: Shah rukh khan: courage, determination, and a single-minded vision. These are the qualities the biggest achievers have in common. These are those brave hearts for whom failure is not an option. What looks to us an unconquerable sea, to our next speaker is an irresistible stage she was born to perform on. So let's dive straight into the story of our fearless speaker, bhakti sharma, who's making waves in the world of long-distance swimming. Bhakti sharma. (applause)bhakti sharma: imagine, in the scorching rajasthan heat, on a hot summer afternoon, a two-and-a-half-year-old riding on a moped behind her mom, not knowing where they were headed. And 20 minutes later, that two-and-a-half-year-old finds herself completely submerged in water.
polished: Shah Rukh Khan: Courage, determination, and a single-minded vision - these are the qualities that the biggest achievers share. These brave hearts are the ones for whom failure is not an option. What may seem like an unconquerable sea to us is an irresistible stage for our next speaker, one she was born to conquer. Let's dive straight into the story of our fearless speaker, Bhakti Sharma, who's making a splash in the world of long-distance swimming. Bhakti Sharma. (applause) Bhakti Sharma: Imagine a scorching summer afternoon in Rajasthan, a two-and-a-half-year-old riding pillion on a moped with her mom, unaware of their destination. Twenty minutes later, that same two-and-a-half-year-old finds herself completely submerged in water.

original: I'm going to talk about a technology that we're developing at oxford now, that we think is going to change the way that computer games and hollywood movies are being made. That technology is simulating humans. It's simulated humans with a simulated body and a simulated nervous system to control that body. Now, before i talk more about that technology, let's have a quick look at what human characters look like at the moment in computer games. This is a clip from a game called "grand theft auto 3." we already saw that briefly yesterday. And what you can see is — it is actually a very good game. It's one of the most successful games of all time.
polished: I'd like to discuss a cutting-edge technology currently being developed at Oxford, which we believe has the potential to revolutionize the creation of computer games and Hollywood movies. This technology involves simulating humans, complete with a simulated body and a simulated nervous system that controls it. Before delving deeper into this technology, let's take a brief look at how human characters are currently portrayed in computer games. This clip is from the game "Grand Theft Auto 3," which we touched on briefly yesterday. As you can see, it's a highly acclaimed game, and one of the most successful of all time.

original: Like a lot of people around the world, earlier this summer my friends and i were obsessed with the women's world cup held in france. Here we are, watching these incredible athletes, the goals were amazing, the games were clean and engaging, and at the same time, outside the field, these women are talking about equal pay, and in the case of some countries, any pay at all for their sport. So because we were mildly obsessed, we wanted to watch the games live, and we decided that one of the spanish-speaking networks in the us was the best place for us to start. And it wasn't until a few games into the tournament that a friend of mine talks to me and says, "why does it feel like everything i'm seeing is commercials for makeup and household cleaning products and diets?
polished: Like many people worldwide, my friends and I were captivated by the Women's World Cup in France earlier this summer. As we watched these remarkable athletes in action, we were struck by the incredible goals, the clean and engaging gameplay, and the fact that, off the field, these women were advocating for equal pay - and, in some cases, any pay at all for their sport. Our enthusiasm led us to seek out live broadcasts, and we decided to start with one of the Spanish-speaking networks in the US. It wasn't until a few games into the tournament, however, that a friend pointed out to me, "Have you noticed that the commercials seem to be predominantly for makeup, household cleaning products, and diets?

original: I want to tell you about the future of money. Let's start with a story about this culture that lived in micronesia in the early 1900s, called the yap. Now, i want to tell you about the yap because their form of money is really interesting. They use these limestone discs called rai stones. Now, the yap don't actually move these rai stones around or exchange them the way we do with our coins, because rai stones can get to be pretty massive. The largest is about four tons and 12 feet across. So the yap just keep track of who owns part of what stone.there's a story about these sailors that were transporting a stone across the ocean when they ran into some trouble and the stone actually fell in.
polished: I'd like to share with you the future of money, and to do so, let's begin with a fascinating story about the Yap culture in Micronesia in the early 1900s. The Yap people are particularly noteworthy due to their unique form of currency, which I'd like to highlight. They utilized massive limestone discs known as rai stones. What's intriguing about the Yap's use of rai stones is that they didn't physically move or exchange them as we do with our coins, primarily because these stones can be enormous, with the largest weighing around four tons and measuring 12 feet in diameter. Instead, the Yap simply kept track of who owned which part of a stone. There's an interesting anecdote about a group of sailors who were transporting a stone across the ocean when they encountered trouble, resulting in the stone falling into the water.

original: You’ve been accused of a crime you did not commit. It’s impossible to prove your innocence. If you insist that you’re innocent anyway, you’ll likely be found guilty and executed. But if you confess, apologize, and implicate others for good measure, you’ll go free. Do you give a false confession— or risk a public hanging?this was the choice facing those accused of witchcraft in the village of salem, massachusetts between february 1692 and may 1693. They were the victims of paranoia about the supernatural, misdirected religious fervor— and a justice system that valued repentance over truth.salem was settled in 1626 by puritans, a group of english protestants. Life was strict and isolated for the people of salem. Battles with their native american neighbors and groups of french settlers were commonplace.
polished: You've been falsely accused of a crime and face an impossible task of proving your innocence. Insisting on your innocence may lead to a guilty verdict and execution, whereas confessing, apologizing, and implicating others could secure your freedom. The choice is between giving a false confession or risking a public hanging. This was the dilemma faced by those accused of witchcraft in Salem, Massachusetts, between February 1692 and May 1693. They fell victim to paranoia surrounding the supernatural, misguided religious zeal, and a justice system that prioritized repentance over truth. Founded by English Puritans in 1626, Salem was a strict and isolated community. The villagers frequently clashed with their Native American neighbors and French settlers, leading to a life of constant turmoil.

original: There are currently hundreds of thousands of people on transplant lists, waiting for critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers that could save their lives. Unfortunately, there aren’t nearly enough donor organs available to fill that demand.what if instead of waiting, we could create brand-new, customized organs from scratch? that’s the idea behind bioprinting, a branch of regenerative medicine currently under development. We’re not able to print complex organs just yet, but simpler tissues including blood vessels and tubes responsible for nutrient and waste exchange are already in our grasp.bioprinting is a biological cousin of 3-d printing, a technique that deposits layers of material on top of each other to construct a three-dimensional object one slice at a time.
polished: There are currently hundreds of thousands of people on transplant lists, awaiting critical organs such as kidneys, hearts, and livers that could potentially save their lives. However, the availability of donor organs falls significantly short of meeting this demand. What if, instead of waiting, we could create brand-new, customized organs from scratch? This is the concept behind bioprinting, a branch of regenerative medicine that is currently in development. Although we are not yet capable of printing complex organs, we have already made progress in creating simpler tissues, including blood vessels and tubes responsible for nutrient and waste exchange. Bioprinting is a biological counterpart to 3D printing, a technique that constructs three-dimensional objects by depositing layers of material on top of each other, one slice at a time.

original: Good afternoon, i'm proud to be here at tedxkrakow. I'll try to speak a little bit today about a phenomenon which can, and actually is changing the world, and whose name is people power. I'll start with an anecdote, or for those of you who are monty python lovers, a monty python type of sketch. Here it is.it is december 15, 2010. Somebody gives you a bet: you will look at a crystal ball, and you will see the future; the future will be accurate. But you need to share it with the world. Ok, curiosity killed the cat, you take the bet, you look at the crystal ball. One hour later, you're sitting in a building of the national tv, in a top show, and you tell the story.
polished: Good afternoon, I'm honored to be here at TEDxKrakow. Today, I'll be discussing a phenomenon that has the potential to, and indeed is, changing the world - people power. To begin, I'd like to share an anecdote, or for those familiar with Monty Python, a sketch reminiscent of their style. Here it goes: Imagine it's December 15, 2010. Someone offers you a bet: you gaze into a crystal ball, and the future it reveals will be accurate, but you must share it with the world. Your curiosity gets the better of you, and you take the bet. An hour later, you find yourself in a national TV building, on a top-rated show, recounting the story.

original: We're going to begin in 1964. Bob dylan is 23 years old, and his career is just reaching its pinnacle. He's been christened the voice of a generation, and he's churning out classic songs at a seemingly impossible rate, but there's a small minority of dissenters, and they claim that bob dylan is stealing other people's songs.2004. Brian burton, aka danger mouse, takes the beatles' "white album," combines it with jay-z's "the black album" to create "the grey album." "the grey album" becomes an immediate sensation online, and the beatles' record company sends out countless cease-and-desist letters for "unfair competition and dilution of our valuable property. "now, "the grey album" is a remix.
polished: We're going to begin in 1964, when Bob Dylan, at just 23 years old, was reaching the pinnacle of his career. Having been hailed as the voice of a generation, he was producing classic songs at an incredible rate. However, a small minority of critics emerged, accusing Dylan of stealing other people's songs. Fast forward to 2004, when Brian Burton, aka Danger Mouse, combined The Beatles' "White Album" with Jay-Z's "The Black Album" to create "The Grey Album." This innovative remix became an instant online sensation, prompting The Beatles' record company to issue numerous cease-and-desist letters, citing "unfair competition and dilution of our valuable property.

original: Well, that's kind of an obvious statement up there. I started with that sentence about 12 years ago, and i started in the context of developing countries, but you're sitting here from every corner of the world. So if you think of a map of your country, i think you'll realize that for every country on earth, you could draw little circles to say, "these are places where good teachers won't go." on top of that, those are the places from where trouble comes. So we have an ironic problem — good teachers don't want to go to just those places where they're needed the most.i started in 1999 to try and address this problem with an experiment, which was a very simple experiment in new delhi.
polished: That's a rather obvious statement, isn't it? I began with that sentence about 12 years ago, initially focusing on developing countries, but now I'm speaking to an audience from every corner of the globe. If you envision a map of your country, you'll likely notice that every nation on earth has areas that can be circled and labeled as places where good teachers are reluctant to go. Ironically, these are often the same areas from which many problems originate. We're faced with a paradox – good teachers tend to avoid the very places where they're needed most. In 1999, I embarked on an experiment in New Delhi to address this issue, and it was a remarkably simple one.

original: Currently, most refugees live in the cities rather than in the refugee camps. We represent over 60 percent of the number of refugees globally. With the majority of refugees living in urban areas, there is a strong need for a paradigm shift and new thinking. Rather than wasting money on building walls, it would be better to spend on programs to help refugees to help themselves. (applause)we always have to leave behind all our possessions. But not our skills and knowledge. If allowed to live a productive life, refugees can help themselves and contribute to the development of their host country.i was born in the city called bukavu, south kivu, in the democratic republic of congo. I am the fifth-born in a family of 12 children.
polished: Currently, the majority of refugees reside in cities rather than in refugee camps, with our community accounting for over 60 percent of the global refugee population. Given the prevalence of urban refugee settlements, there is a pressing need for a paradigm shift and innovative thinking. Instead of investing in physical barriers, it would be more effective to allocate resources to programs that empower refugees to become self-sufficient. (applause) Although we often have to abandon our possessions, we retain our skills and knowledge. If permitted to lead productive lives, refugees can not only support themselves but also contribute to the development of their host countries. I was born in Bukavu, South Kivu, in the Democratic Republic of Congo, and I am the fifth of 12 children in my family.

original: I have two questions for you. One: whose shoulders do you stand on? and two: what do you stand for? these are two questions that i always begin my poetry workshops with students because at times, poetry can seem like this dead art form for old white men who just seem like they were born to be old, like, you know, benjamin button or something. And i ask my students these two questions, and then i share how i answer them, which is in these three sentences that go: i am the daughter of black writers, who are descended from freedom fighters who broke their chains and changed the world. They call me. And these are words i repeat in a mantra before every single poetry performance. In fact, i was doing it in the corner over there. I was making faces.
polished: I have two questions for you: whose shoulders do you stand on, and what do you stand for? These are the questions I always begin my poetry workshops with, as I believe they help students connect with the art form on a deeper level. At times, poetry can seem like a stagnant art form associated with older white men, as if they were born with a predetermined fate, like Benjamin Button. To help my students find their own voice, I ask them these questions and then share my own answers. I am the daughter of black writers, who are descended from freedom fighters who broke free from their chains and changed the world. They call me. I repeat these words as a mantra before every poetry performance, a ritual that helps me center myself. In fact, I was doing just that in the corner, preparing myself for this moment.

original: (breathes in)(breathes out)so, i didn't always make my living from music. For about the five years after graduating from an upstanding liberal arts university, this was my day job. (laughter)i was a self-employed living statue called the eight-foot bride, and i love telling people i did this for a job, because everybody always wants to know, who are these freaks in real life. (laughter)hello.i painted myself white one day, stood on a box, put a hat or a can at my feet, and when someone came by and dropped in money, i handed them a flower — and some intense eye contact. And if they didn't take the flower, i threw in a gesture of sadness and longing — as they walked away.
polished: (pauses) So, I didn't always make a living from music. For about five years after graduating from a reputable liberal arts university, this was my day job. (laughter) I was a self-employed living statue, known as the eight-foot bride, and I love sharing this with people, because everyone always wonders, what's the real story behind these street performers. (laughter) Hello. I would paint myself white, stand on a box, place a hat or can at my feet, and when someone came by and dropped in money, I'd hand them a flower – along with some intense eye contact. And if they didn't take the flower, I'd add a gesture of sadness and longing as they walked away.

original: On october 4, 1957, the world watched in awe and fear as the soviet union launched sputnik, the world's first man-made satellite, into space. This little metal ball, smaller than two feet in diameter, launched a space race between the u.s. And u.s.s.r. That would last for eighteen years and change the world as we know it. Sputnik was actually not the first piece of human technology to enter space. That superlative goes to the v-2 rocket used by germany in missile attacks against allied cities as a last-ditch effort in the final years of world war ii. It wasn't very effective, but, at the end of the war, both the u.s. And u.s.s.r. Had captured the technology and the scientists that had developed it and began using them for their own projects.
polished: On October 4, 1957, the world witnessed a historic moment with a mix of awe and trepidation as the Soviet Union launched Sputnik, the world's first artificial satellite, into space. This small metal sphere, measuring less than two feet in diameter, sparked a space race between the United States and the Soviet Union that would span eighteen years and forever alter the world as we knew it. Although Sputnik was not the first human-made object to enter space, it holds a significant place in history. The V-2 rocket, used by Germany in missile attacks against Allied cities during the final years of World War II, holds the distinction of being the first piece of human technology to reach space. Although the V-2 rocket was not particularly effective, both the United States and the Soviet Union captured the technology and the scientists behind it after the war, utilizing them for their own projects.

original: I am a cultural omnivore, one whose daily commute is made possible by attachment to an ipod — an ipod that contains wagner and mozart, pop diva christina aguilera, country singer josh turner, gangsta rap artist kirk franklin, concerti, symphonies and more and more. I'm a voracious reader, a reader who deals with ian mcewan down to stephanie meyer. I have read the twilight tetralogy. And one who lives for my home theater, a home theater where i devour dvds, video on demand and a lot of television. For me, "law & order: svu," tina fey and "30 rock" and "judge judy" — "the people are real, the cases are real, the rulings are final.
polished: I'm a cultural omnivore, whose daily commute is fueled by an iPod filled with a diverse range of artists, from classical composers like Wagner and Mozart, to pop diva Christina Aguilera, country singer Josh Turner, and gangsta rap artist Kirk Franklin. My music library also features concerti, symphonies, and much more. As a voracious reader, my tastes span from Ian McEwan to Stephanie Meyer, and I've even devoured the entire Twilight tetralogy. At home, I indulge in my home theater, where I watch a wide array of DVDs, video on demand, and television shows. My favorite programs include "Law & Order: SVU," Tina Fey's "30 Rock," and "Judge Judy," where the cases are real, the people are real, and the rulings are final.

original: [citizens of the world][we face a global crisis of unprecedented scale][please stand by for a message from ... ][the secretary-general of the united nations antónio guterres]the climate emergency is the defining crisis of our time. We are in a race against time, and we are losing. There is a growing tide of impatience, especially among young people, with global inaction. We need more ambition from all: governments, cities, businesses, investors and people everywhere. So i'm pleased you are launching ted countdown. Your influence and ideas can help accelerate momentum for a carbon-neutral world by 2050. That is the only way to avert the worst impacts of global heating. We have the tools, the science and the resources. Let us now get into this race with political will and energy.
polished: Citizens of the world, we are facing a global crisis of unprecedented scale. Please stand by for a message from the Secretary-General of the United Nations, António Guterres. The climate emergency is the defining crisis of our time. We are in a desperate race against time, and unfortunately, we are falling behind. A growing tide of impatience, particularly among young people, is rising in response to global inaction. We urgently need greater ambition from all stakeholders: governments, cities, businesses, investors, and individuals worldwide. I am pleased to see the launch of TED Countdown, as your influence and innovative ideas can help accelerate momentum towards a carbon-neutral world by 2050. This is the only way to mitigate the worst impacts of global heating. We possess the necessary tools, scientific knowledge, and resources. Now, let us summon the political will and energy to join this critical race.

original: Menstruation. A simple word describing a natural biological process, weighed down by centuries of stigma, has been transformed into something most of us can only speak about in whispers. But why? as i speak to you right now, more than 800 million women around the world are having a period. None of us would exist without it, and yet it remains an "embarrassing" subject to broach. From my experience and that of the women around me, i can tell you that it's exhausting.it's exhausting to carefully take out a brown paper bag hiding a pad, stuffing it into your pocket in the middle of a class and rushing to the washroom as discreetly as possible. It's exhausting to sit through lessons and meetings pretending to be absolutely normal, while internally crying out from intense period cramps.
polished: Menstruation - a straightforward term for a natural biological process - has been shrouded in centuries of stigma, forcing many of us to discuss it in hushed tones. But why is this the case? As I speak, over 800 million women worldwide are experiencing their period. Without it, none of us would exist, yet it remains a subject often deemed too embarrassing to openly discuss. From my own experiences and those of the women around me, I can attest that it's draining. It's draining to discreetly retrieve a pad from a brown paper bag, hastily stuffing it into your pocket during class, and then rushing to the washroom as unobtrusively as possible. It's equally exhausting to sit through lessons and meetings, pretending to be perfectly normal, while silently suffering from intense period cramps.

original: The world's largest and most devastating environmental and industrial project is situated in the heart of the largest and most intact forest in the world, canada's boreal forest. It stretches right across northern canada, in labrador, it's home to the largest remaining wild caribou herd in the world: the george river caribou herd, numbering approximately 400,000 animals. Unfortunately, when i was there, i couldn't find one of them, but you have the antlers as proof.all across the boreal, we're blessed with this incredible abundance of wetlands. Wetlands, globally, are one of the most endangered ecosystems. They're absolutely critical ecosystems, they clean air, they clean water, they sequester large amounts of greenhouse gases, and they're home to a huge diversity of species.
polished: The world's largest and most devastating environmental and industrial project is located in the heart of the world's largest and most intact forest, Canada's boreal forest. Spanning across northern Canada, including Labrador, it is home to the world's largest remaining wild caribou herd, the George River caribou herd, which numbers approximately 400,000 animals. Although I was unable to spot any during my visit, the antlers serve as proof of their presence. Throughout the boreal region, we are fortunate to have an incredible abundance of wetlands. Globally, wetlands are one of the most endangered ecosystems, yet they are crucial for cleaning the air and water, sequestering significant amounts of greenhouse gases, and supporting a vast array of species.

original: Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, made of fields, plains and gardens. Four brothers wandered this celestial realm. They had no family other than each other— they didn’t even know who their parents were. One of the brothers, deminan, looked different from the others. His skin was covered in painful scabs, and he wondered why he alone had been marked with this affliction.one day, while the supreme spirit yaya was out in his gardens, deminan and his brothers snuck into yaya’s house. After feasting and exploring, they spotted a giant gourd hanging in the corner. But as they tried to look inside the gourd, they dropped it.
polished: In the world of the gods, which existed long before the dawn of humanity, vast fields, plains, and gardens stretched as far as the eye could see. Four brothers, bound together by their shared isolation, wandered this celestial realm, their only family being each other, for they had no knowledge of their parents. One brother, Deminan, stood out from the rest, his skin marred by painful scabs that left him wondering why he alone bore this affliction. One day, while the supreme spirit Yaya tended to his gardens, Deminan and his brothers snuck into Yaya's house, where they indulged in a feast and explored the surroundings. Their curiosity eventually led them to a giant gourd hanging in the corner, but as they attempted to peer inside, it slipped from their grasp and fell.

original: So, i had graduated seven years ago from berkeley with a dual degree in molecular and cell biology and linguistics, and i had gone to a career fair here on campus, where i'd gotten an interview with a start-up called theranos. And at the time, there wasn't really that much information about the company, but the little that was there was really impressive. Essentially, what the company was doing was creating a medical device where you would be able to run your entire blood panel on a finger-stick of blood. So you wouldn't have to get a big needle stuck in your arm in order to get your blood test done. So this was interesting not only because it was less painful, but also, it could potentially open the door to predictive diagnostics.
polished: I had graduated seven years ago from Berkeley with a dual degree in molecular and cell biology and linguistics. Following graduation, I attended a career fair on campus, where I secured an interview with a start-up called Theranos. At the time, there was limited information available about the company, but what I found was truly impressive. Essentially, Theranos was developing a medical device that would enable individuals to run their entire blood panel using just a finger-stick of blood, eliminating the need for a large needle injection in the arm. This concept was intriguing not only because it was less painful, but also because it had the potential to open the door to predictive diagnostics.

original: My journey to become a polar specialist, photographing, specializing in the polar regions, began when i was four years old, when my family moved from southern canada to northern baffin island, up by greenland. There we lived with the inuit in the tiny inuit community of 200 inuit people, where [we] were one of three non-inuit families. And in this community, we didn't have a television; we didn't have computers, obviously, radio. We didn't even have a telephone. All of my time was spent outside with the inuit, playing. The snow and the ice were my sandbox, and the inuit were my teachers. And that's where i became truly obsessed with this polar realm.
polished: My journey to becoming a polar specialist, photographing and specializing in the polar regions, began when I was four years old, when my family relocated from southern Canada to northern Baffin Island, near Greenland. There, we lived among the Inuit in a small community of 200 Inuit people, where we were one of only three non-Inuit families. In this community, we didn't have the luxury of modern conveniences like television, computers, or even a telephone. As a result, I spent most of my time outdoors with the Inuit, playing and learning. The snow and ice served as my playground, and the Inuit were my guides. It was there that I developed a deep fascination with the polar realm.

original: We're seen as the organization that is the bucket for failed social policy. I can't define who comes to us or how long they stay. That's our job: contain them, control them.over the years, as a prison system, as a nation, and as a society, we've become very good at that, but that shouldn't make you happy. Today we incarcerate more people per capita than any other country in the world. We have more black men in prison today than were under slavery in 1850.
polished: We're perceived as the organization that serves as a last resort for failed social policies. I have no control over who comes to us or the duration of their stay. We receive individuals for whom all other avenues have been exhausted, people who have slipped through the cracks of every other social safety net. Since they can't be contained elsewhere, it falls to us to do so. Our role is to contain and control them. Over the years, as a prison system, a nation, and a society, we've become adept at this task, but that's not something to be proud of. Currently, we have the highest incarceration rate per capita of any country in the world. Notably, there are more black men incarcerated today than there were enslaved in 1850.

original: I'd like to take you on the epic quest of the rosetta spacecraft. To escort and land the probe on a comet, this has been my passion for the past two years. In order to do that, i need to explain to you something about the origin of the solar system.when we go back four and a half billion years, there was a cloud of gas and dust. In the center of this cloud, our sun formed and ignited. Along with that, what we now know as planets, comets and asteroids formed. What then happened, according to theory, is that when the earth had cooled down a bit after its formation, comets massively impacted the earth and delivered water to earth. They probably also delivered complex organic material to earth, and that may have bootstrapped the emergence of life.
polished: I'd like to take you on the epic quest of the Rosetta spacecraft. Escorting and landing the probe on a comet has been my passion for the past two years. To set the stage, I need to explain the origin of our solar system. Going back 4.5 billion years, a vast cloud of gas and dust existed. At its center, our sun formed and ignited, and with it, the planets, comets, and asteroids we know today took shape. According to theory, after the Earth cooled down following its formation, comets collided with our planet, delivering water and likely complex organic materials that may have kick-started the emergence of life.

original: Chris anderson: hello, ted community, welcome back for another live conversation. It's a big one today, as big as they get. You know, when we created this "build back better" series our thought was how could we address issues arising out of the pandemic, how could we imagine building back from that. But the events of this past week, the horrific death of george floyd and the daily protests that have followed, i mean, they provided a new urgency which we, of course, simply have to address. I mean, can we build back better from this? i think before we can even start to answer that question, we just have to seek to understand the immensity of this moment.whitney pennington rodgers: that's right, chris.
polished: Chris Anderson: Hello, TED community, welcome back for another live conversation. Today's discussion is particularly significant, one of the most substantial we've had. When we launched the 'Build Back Better' series, our goal was to explore ways to address the challenges arising from the pandemic and reimagine a path forward. However, the tragic events of the past week, including the devastating death of George Floyd and the subsequent daily protests, have introduced a new sense of urgency that we must acknowledge. Can we truly build back better from this? I believe that before we can even begin to answer that question, we must first strive to comprehend the magnitude of this moment. Whitney Pennington Rodgers: That's right, Chris.

original: In 1903, the president of the united states took a three-day camping trip in california’s yosemite valley. President theodore roosevelt slept in a grove of towering sequoia trees, camped in a snowstorm, and spent hours talking around the campfire with his host and guide, conservationist john muir. Roosevelt famously loved the outdoors, but muir had invited him there for more than just camping: yosemite was in danger.though yosemite became protected land in 1864, the valley was still at risk for overdevelopment in 1903. It was at the heart of a decades-old struggle to set aside land for both preservation and public use— two goals that were much easier said than done.the battle over yosemite began with the 1849 gold rush, when miners surged west, seeking gold in the sierra nevada foothills.
polished: In 1903, the President of the United States embarked on a three-day camping trip in California's Yosemite Valley. President Theodore Roosevelt spent the night in a grove of towering sequoia trees, braved a snowstorm, and engaged in hours of conversation around the campfire with his host and guide, renowned conservationist John Muir. While Roosevelt was well-known for his love of the outdoors, Muir's invitation was motivated by more than just a desire for a camping trip: Yosemite was facing a grave threat. Although Yosemite had been designated as protected land in 1864, the valley remained vulnerable to overdevelopment in 1903, lying at the heart of a decades-long struggle to balance preservation and public use – a delicate balance that proved far easier to articulate than achieve. The battle to safeguard Yosemite's future had begun decades earlier, with the 1849 gold rush, which drew a surge of miners to the Sierra Nevada foothills in search of gold.

original: Hello. This is my first trip, first time in life i'm outside of the walls of gaza. I'm so happy to be here. (applause)my ambition always was to be a pilot, to fly a plane, to feel free to fly the sky, to touch the sky. But that didn't happen. Simply, i live in gaza, there is no airport. All borders are closed on every side. We live in one of the biggest prisons in the world. The only thing i can do is just to look up to the sky. On some days, we are lucky if we have electricity for four or five hours. When it's cold, we make a fire on the front or on the roof of our homes.
polished: Hello. This is my first trip, and the first time in my life I've been outside the walls of Gaza. I'm thrilled to be here. (applause) My lifelong ambition has always been to become a pilot, to fly a plane, to experience the freedom of soaring through the sky, and to touch the clouds. Unfortunately, that dream never took off. Simply put, I live in Gaza, where there is no airport, and all borders are closed on every side. We are essentially living in one of the world's largest prisons. The only thing I can do is gaze up at the sky. On some days, we're fortunate if we have electricity for four or five hours. When it's cold, we resort to making fires on the front porch or on the roof of our homes.

original: I am sorry i cannot show you my face, because if i do, the bad guys will come for me.my journey started 14 years ago. I was a young reporter. I had just come out of college.then i got a scoop. The scoop was quite a very simple story. Police officers were taking bribes from hawkers who were hawking on the streets. As a young reporter, i thought that i should do it in a different way, so that it has a maximum impact, since everybody knew that it was happening, and yet there was nothing that was keeping it out of the system.so i decided to go there and act as a seller. As part of selling, i was able to document the hard core evidence. The impact was great. It was fantastic.this was what many call immersion journalism, or undercover journalism.
polished: I apologize, but I must keep my face hidden, as revealing my identity would put me in danger from those who wish to harm me. My journey began 14 years ago, when I was a young and ambitious reporter, fresh out of college. I stumbled upon a scoop that, although straightforward, had the potential to create significant impact. The story was about police officers accepting bribes from street vendors, a practice that was widely known but had yet to be exposed. Determined to make a difference, I decided to take an unconventional approach. I went undercover, posing as a vendor, and was able to gather concrete evidence of the corruption. The impact was substantial, and it was a prime example of what is often referred to as immersion or undercover journalism.

original: One simple vitamin can reduce your risk of heart disease.eating chocolate reduces stress in students.new drug prolongs lives of patients with rare disease.health headlines like these are published every day, sometimes making opposite claims from each other. There can be a disconnect between broad, attention-grabbing headlines and the often specific, incremental results of the medical research they cover. So how can you avoid being misled by grabby headlines?the best way to assess a headline’s credibility is to look at the original research it reports on. We’ve come up with a hypothetical research scenario for each of these three headlines.keep watching for the explanation of the first example; then pause at the headline to answer the question. polished: A single vitamin can significantly reduce the risk of heart disease. Eating chocolate can alleviate stress in students. A new drug can prolong the lives of patients with a rare disease. Such health headlines are published daily, often presenting conflicting claims. However, there can be a disconnect between attention-grabbing headlines and the specific, incremental results of the medical research they cover. To avoid being misled by sensational headlines, it's essential to examine the original research they report on. We've created hypothetical research scenarios for each of these three headlines. Continue watching for an explanation of the first example, then pause at the headline to answer the question. These scenarios are simplified for clarity.

original: So, when i was 14, my family was in the process of adopting my little brothers from ethiopia. And one day my mom asked, "what day should we put for their birthday?" "uh, the day they were born, obviously?" ridiculous question. And then my mom said, "well, kristen, neither of your little brothers have a birth certificate, so how do you suggest we find out when that was?" mind blown. Now, 20 years later, i'm still working on it, except instead of trying to solve the mystery of my brothers' missing birth certificates, i try to solve this problem globally.so what do birth certificates have to do with international development?
polished: When I was 14, my family was in the process of adopting my younger brothers from Ethiopia. One day, my mom asked, "What date should we use for their birthdays?" I thought it was a ridiculous question, responding, "The day they were born, obviously?" But then my mom explained, "Kristen, neither of your brothers has a birth certificate, so how do you suggest we determine their birthdates?" I was taken aback. Twenty years later, I'm still working on this issue, but instead of trying to solve the mystery of my brothers' missing birth certificates, I'm tackling the problem on a global scale. So, what's the connection between birth certificates and international development?

original: Imagine if you could plug your brain into a machine that would bring you ultimate pleasure for the rest of your life. If you were given the choice to sign up for that kind of existence, would you? that's the question philosopher robert nozick posed through a thought experiment he called the experience machine. The experiment asks us to consider a world in which scientists have developed a machine that would simulate real life while guaranteeing experiences of only pleasure and never pain. The catch? you have to permanently leave reality behind, but you'll hardly know the difference. Your experiences will be indistinguishable from reality. Life's natural ups and downs will just be replaced with an endless series of ups. Sounds great, right?
polished: Imagine being able to plug your brain into a machine that would provide you with ultimate pleasure for the rest of your life. If given the choice, would you opt for such an existence? This is the question philosopher Robert Nozick posed through his thought-provoking experiment, known as the Experience Machine. The experiment invites us to consider a world where scientists have developed a machine capable of simulating real life, guaranteeing experiences of pure pleasure and eliminating pain entirely. The trade-off, however, is that you must permanently relinquish reality, although the simulated experiences would be virtually indistinguishable from the real thing. Life's natural ebbs and flows would be replaced with an endless succession of highs. At first glance, this may seem like an attractive proposition.

original: I would like to tell you about the most embarrassing thing that has ever happened to me in my years of working as a palliative care physician. This happened a couple of years ago. I was asked as a consultant to see a woman in her 70s — retired english professor who had pancreatic cancer. I was asked to see her because she had pain, nausea, vomiting ... When i went to see her, we talked about those symptoms and in the course of that consultation, she asked me whether i thought that medical marijuana might help her. I thought back to everything that i had learned in medical school about medical marijuana, which didn't take very long because i had learned absolutely nothing.
polished: I'd like to share with you the most embarrassing experience I've had during my years as a palliative care physician. This incident occurred a couple of years ago. I was consulted to see a woman in her 70s, a retired English professor, who was battling pancreatic cancer. She was experiencing pain, nausea, and vomiting, which prompted the request for my expertise. During our consultation, we discussed her symptoms, and she inquired about the potential benefits of medical marijuana. As I reflected on my medical school education, I realized that I had received no formal training on the subject of medical marijuana, leaving me with a significant knowledge gap.

original: For the past 24 years, i have been a firefighter in huntington, west virginia. As firefighters, my team and i are tasked with saving lives and property from such disasters as car wrecks, house fires and also life-threatening medical emergencies. I am a woman leading a department in a male-dominated profession.and 10 years ago, i decided to increase my medical knowledge and i received a nursing degree. That was because it became clear that the next big threat facing not only my city, but other cities around the country, was not the one-and-done disaster, where you can ride in like the cavalry, as a firefighter, put out the fire and leave, feeling like you have made a difference and everything is ok.
polished: For the past 24 years, I have served as a firefighter in Huntington, West Virginia. As firefighters, my team and I are responsible for saving lives and property from disasters such as car wrecks, house fires, and life-threatening medical emergencies. As a woman leading a department in a male-dominated profession, I have faced unique challenges. Ten years ago, I decided to expand my medical knowledge by pursuing a nursing degree. This decision was driven by the realization that the next major threat facing not only my city, but also cities across the country, was not the typical one-and-done disaster, where firefighters could simply respond, put out the fire, and leave feeling like they had made a difference, with everything back to normal.

original: Where does all the carbon we release go? carbon works in a natural cycle, present in all living things: in the soil, in the oceans, in the atmosphere and in rocks deep underground. When plants and other living things die, much of their stored carbon makes its way back to the atmosphere until new plants grow and reabsorb the carbon.but over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life becomes rock and some becomes fossil fuels: coal, oil and natural gas. Natural events like volcanic eruptions release some of the carbon trapped in rock. And human activities, like burning fossil fuels, also release some of that prehistoric carbon.today, humans release around 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year.
polished: Where does all the carbon we release go? Carbon operates within a natural cycle, present in all living organisms: in the soil, oceans, atmosphere, and deep underground rocks. When plants and other living organisms die, a significant portion of their stored carbon is released back into the atmosphere, only to be reabsorbed by new plant growth. However, over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life is transformed into rock and fossil fuels, such as coal, oil, and natural gas. Natural events, like volcanic eruptions, release some of the carbon trapped in rock, while human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels, also release prehistoric carbon. Today, human activities release approximately 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet combined each year.

original: Even nature's most disgusting creatures have important secrets, but who would want a swarm of cockroaches coming towards them?yet one of the greatest differences between natural and human technologies relates to robustness. Robust systems are stable in complex and new environments. Remarkably, cockroaches can self-stabilize running over rough terrain. When we put a jet pack on them, or give them a perturbation like an earthquake, we discovered that their wonderfully tuned legs allow them to self-stabilize without using any of their brainpower. They can go over complex terrain like grass, no problem, and not get destabilized. We discovered a new behavior where, because of their shape, they actually roll automatically to their side to go through this artificial test bit of grass.robust systems can perform multiple tasks with the same structure. Here's a new behavior we've discovered.
polished: Even nature's most reviled creatures hold important secrets, but who would want a swarm of cockroaches approaching them? Yet, one of the greatest differences between natural and human technologies lies in robustness. Robust systems remain stable in complex and unfamiliar environments. Notably, cockroaches can self-stabilize while running over rough terrain. When we equipped them with a jet pack or subjected them to a perturbation like an earthquake, we found that their remarkably tuned legs allowed them to self-stabilize without expending any brainpower. They can navigate complex terrain, such as grass, with ease and without becoming destabilized. We also discovered a new behavior, where, due to their shape, they automatically roll onto their side to pass through a simulated grass environment. Robust systems can perform multiple tasks using the same structure, and we have discovered another example of this behavior.

original: These are grim economic times, fellow tedsters, grim economic times indeed. And so, i would like to cheer you up with one of the great, albeit largely unknown, commercial success stories of the past 20 years. Comparable, in its own very peculiar way, to the achievements of microsoft or google. And it's an industry which has bucked the current recession with equanimity. But in the last two decades, it has experienced an unprecedented expansion, now accounting for roughly 15 percent of the world's gdp. polished: These are indeed grim economic times, fellow tedsters. To lift your spirits, I'd like to share one of the most remarkable, albeit lesser-known, commercial success stories of the past 20 years. In its own unique way, it's comparable to the achievements of Microsoft or Google. Notably, this industry has weathered the current recession with remarkable resilience. I'm referring to organized crime. While it's true that organized crime has a long history, its expansion over the last two decades has been unprecedented, now accounting for approximately 15 percent of the world's GDP. I prefer to call it the global shadow economy, or "McMafia" for short. So, what sparked this extraordinary growth in cross-border crime?

original: If you ask people about what part of psychology do they think is hard, and you say, "well, what about thinking and emotions?" most people will say, "emotions are terribly hard. They're incredibly complex. They can't — i have no idea of how they work. But thinking is really very straightforward: it's just sort of some kind of logical reasoning, or something. But that's not the hard part. "so here's a list of problems that come up. One nice problem is, what do we do about health? the other day, i was reading something, and the person said probably the largest single cause of disease is handshaking in the west.
polished: If you ask people which aspect of psychology they find most challenging, and you suggest "thinking and emotions," most will respond that emotions are extremely difficult to grasp due to their complexity. However, this perspective overlooks the intricacies of thinking. To illustrate this, consider the following problems. One notable issue is addressing health concerns. I recently came across an interesting point - a person suggested that handshaking in Western cultures is likely the single largest cause of disease.

original: What is a parent?what is a parent?it's not an easy question. Today we have adoption, stepfamilies, surrogate mothers. Many parents face tough questions and tough decisions. Shall we tell our child about the sperm donation? if so, when? what words to use? sperm donors are often referred to as "biological fathers," but should we really be using the word "father? "as a philosopher and social scientist, i have been studying these questions about the concept of parenthood. But today, i will talk to you about what i learned from talking to parents and children. I will show you that they know what matters most in a family, even though their family looks a little different.
polished: What is a parent? It's not an easy question. With the rise of adoption, stepfamilies, and surrogate mothers, the concept of parenthood has become increasingly complex. Many parents face tough questions and difficult decisions. Should we inform our child about the sperm donation, and if so, when and how? Sperm donors are often referred to as "biological fathers," but is it accurate to use the term "father" in this context? As a philosopher and social scientist, I have been studying these questions surrounding the concept of parenthood. However, today I will share with you what I have learned from speaking with parents and children. Through their stories, I will demonstrate that they understand what truly matters in a family, even if their family structure may differ from the traditional norm.

original: When i look in the mirror today, i see a justice and education scholar at columbia university, a youth mentor, an activist and a future new york state senator. (cheering)i see all of that and a man who spent a quarter of his life in state prison — six years, to be exact, starting as a teenager on rikers island for an act that nearly cost a man his life. But what got me from there to here wasn't the punishment i faced as a teenager in adult prison or the harshness of our legal system. Instead, it was a learning environment of a classroom that introduced me to something i didn't think was possible for me or our justice system as a whole.a few weeks before my release on parole, a counselor encouraged me to enroll in a new college course being offered in the prison.
polished: When I look in the mirror today, I see a justice and education scholar at Columbia University, a youth mentor, an activist, and a future New York State Senator. (cheering) I see all of that and a man who spent a quarter of his life in state prison – six years, to be exact, starting as a teenager on Rikers Island for an act that nearly cost a man his life. However, it wasn't the punishment I faced as a teenager in adult prison or the harshness of our legal system that transformed me. Instead, it was the learning environment of a classroom that introduced me to possibilities I never thought existed for me or our justice system as a whole. A few weeks before my release on parole, a counselor encouraged me to enroll in a new college course being offered within the prison.

original: We need to build a weather service for water. Yet, until we collectively demand accountability, the incentives to fund it will not exist.the first time i spoke at a conference was here at ted, eight years ago. Fresh out of grad school, little did i know that in those few minutes onstage, i was framing the questions i was going to be asked for the next decade. I had a lot to learn.it was seductive, believing that our biggest water quality problems persist because they're so hard to identify. polished: We need to establish a comprehensive weather service for water, but until we collectively demand accountability, the incentives to fund it will not be in place. The first time I spoke at a conference was here at TED, eight years ago. Fresh out of graduate school, I had no idea that those few minutes on stage would frame the questions I would be asked for the next decade. Like many 20-somethings, I naively expected to solve the world's problems – specifically, the world's water problems – with my technology. I had a lot to learn. It was a seductive idea to believe that our biggest water quality problems persist because they're so difficult to identify. I presumed that all we needed were simpler, faster, and more affordable sensors. I was mistaken.

original: Indeed, for 20 years, i worked in finance. I knew everything about finance, for sure. I knew the global economy because it was my life. All the topics that you could bring up about ecology, the end of the world, etc., that i knew like the back of my hand i didn't really believe in them. polished: For 20 years, I worked in finance, and I was confident that I knew everything there was to know about the field. The global economy was my life, and I was well-versed in all aspects of it. I was also familiar with various topics such as ecology and the potential end of the world, but I didn't truly believe in their significance. However, in 2007, the subprime crisis and the collapse of major American banks occurred, which was a shocking event that many may still recall. It was a wake-up call for me, and I had several heated discussions with my wife about my job and the limitations of our financial models. The crisis made me realize that I had been mistaken, and that we were, in fact, heading towards disaster.
